{{Use British English|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Jonjo Shelvey | image = Jonjo Shelvey England U21.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Shelvey playing for [[England national under-21 football team|England U21s]] in 2012 | fullname = Jonjo Shelvey<ref>{{Hugman|25287|accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|2|27|df=y}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/4135/Jonjo-Shelvey/overview |title=Jonjo Shelvey: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Romford]], England | height = {{convert|1.84|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/jonjo-shelvey/51243/ |title=J. Shelvey: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=15 March 2019}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubnumber = 8 | youthyears1 = 2001–2002 | youthyears2 = 2002–2004 | youthyears3 = 2004–2008 | youthclubs1 = [[Arsenal F.C. Academy|Arsenal]] | youthclubs2 = [[West Ham United F.C. Reserves and Academy|West Ham United]] | youthclubs3 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C. Academy|Charlton Athletic]] | years1 = 2008–2010 | clubs1 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | caps1 = 42 | goals1 = 7 | years2 = 2010–2013 | clubs2 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps2 = 47 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2011 | clubs3 = → [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] (loan) | caps3 = 10 | goals3 = 6 | years4 = 2013–2016 | clubs4 = [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] | caps4 = 79 | goals4 = 10 | years5 = 2016– | clubs5 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps5 = 100 | goals5 = 6 | nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | nationalyears2 = 2008–2009 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 7 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2009–2010 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 4 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | nationalyears4 = 2011–2013 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 13 | nationalgoals4 = 4 | nationalyears5 = 2012– | nationalteam5 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps5 = 6 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | club-update = 17:30, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 10:30, 15 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Jonjo Shelvey''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|dʒ|ɒ|n|dʒ|oʊ|_|ˈ|ʃ|ɛ|l|v|i}} (born 27 February 1992) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|NewcastU}} club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]].
He began his career at [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], becoming their youngest-ever player at 16 years and 59 days old.<ref name=five>[http://www.metro.co.uk/sport/football/823768-who-is-jonjo-shelvey-top-five-facts Who is Jonjo Shelvey? "Top five things to know about Liverpool new signing"]. ''Metro''. London. Retrieved 30 August 2010.</ref> In 2010, he moved to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] for an initial £1.7 million, spending a brief loan at [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]]. During his time at [[Anfield]], Shelvey was part of a Liverpool squad which won the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] and lost the [[FA Cup]] final in 2012. He joined [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] for £5 million in 2013,<ref name=SwaTransfer /> and Newcastle United for £12 million two and a half years later. A month after joining Newcastle, he was made the team's stand-in [[Captain (association football)|captain]], as the season ended with relegation.
Shelvey played for England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] level and has captained the under-19 team.<ref>{{cite news |title=Shelvey aiming high |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/2010/shelvey-141210 |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref> He won his first cap for [[England national football team|the senior team]] in 2012.
==Club career== ===Charlton Athletic=== [[File:Jonjo.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Shelvey warming up for [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] in 2008]]
Shelvey played in the youth teams of first [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and then [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], the team he had supported as a boy. In 2004,<ref>[https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/354736/Jonjo-Shelvey-You-must-fear-no-one-except-our-manager Profile]. ''Daily Express''. London. Retrieved 22 August 2015.</ref> he moved to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]], making his breakthrough in the [[2007-08 in English football|2007–08]] season after scoring 14 goals in 23 appearances for Charlton's Under 18s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.Liverpool.tv/news/latest-news/shelvey-hopes-to-copy-pal-jack |title=Shelvey hopes to copy pal Jack |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=13 September 2010 |accessdate=13 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331154052/http://www.liverpool.tv/news/latest-news/shelvey-hopes-to-copy-pal-jack |archivedate=31 March 2012 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made his first-team debut on 26 April 2008, starting in a 3–0 away loss against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]]. He became Charlton's youngest-ever player,<ref name=contract/> at the age of 16 years and 59 days – beating the previous holder, [[Paul Konchesky]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Barlow |first=Matt |title=QPR defender Paul Konchesky has fingers in plenty of pies as he opens his own café |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3262432/QPR-defender-Paul-Konchesky-fingers-plenty-pies-opens-cafe.html |accessdate=12 January 2016 |newspaper=Daily Mail |location=London |date=7 October 2015}}{{Unreliable source?|date=April 2017}}</ref> He still had one week of school remaining when he was given his debut by manager [[Alan Pardew]].<ref name=rough/>
On 3 January 2009, Shelvey became Charlton's youngest-ever goal-scorer, with a strike against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in the third round of the [[FA Cup]], opening a 1–1 draw. It was 54 days before his 17th birthday,<ref name=five/> breaking the previous record held by Peter Reeves who was aged 17 years and 100 days when he scored – also against Norwich – in May 1996. Despite interest from several Premier League clubs, on 27 February, his 17th birthday, Shelvey signed his first professional contract with Charlton. He scored his first league goal in the 3–2 win at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 4 April.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_facts/0,19762,11065_3005256,00.html |title=Southampton v Charlton |publisher=Sky Sports |date=4 April 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7972861.stm |title=Southampton 2–3 Charlton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 April 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2010}}</ref> Later that month, he scored in consecutive matches, 2–2 home draws against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] and [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]; the season ended with relegation to [[EFL League One|League One]].{{cn|date=April 2017}}
In September 2009, he signed a one-year contract extension until 2012.<ref name=contract>{{cite news |title=Shelvey signs new Charlton deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/charlton_athletic/8239732.stm |accessdate=12 January 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 September 2009}}</ref> Shelvey contributed four goals from 24 league appearances as the Addicks reached the [[2010 Football League play-offs|promotion play-offs]].{{cn|date=April 2017}}
===Liverpool=== [[File:Jonjo Shelvey meets the fans (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Shelvey with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in 2012]]
Shelvey signed for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in May 2010, for an initial fee of £1.7 million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool sign Charlton's Jonjo Shelvey |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/em/fr/-/sport1/hi/football/teams/l/liverpool/8647872.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2010 |accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref> He made his debut for the club as an extra-time substitute on 22 September in the Reds' shock [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] third-round defeat against [[EFL League Two|League Two]] team [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] at [[Anfield]], with Liverpool losing 4–2 on penalties (with Shelvey scoring in the shootout) after a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool 2–2 Northampton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/9010076.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 September 2010 |accessdate=22 September 2010}}</ref> Shelvey started his first match for the club in Liverpool's [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] group match against [[S.S.C. Napoli|Napoli]] on 21 October 2010, playing the whole 90 minutes match in a 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/9109871.stm |title=Napoli 0–0 Liverpool |date=21 October 2010 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=28 October 2010}}</ref> On 24 October, Shelvey made his [[Premier League]] debut against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] at Anfield, coming on for the final stages in place of [[Raul Meireles]] in the Reds' 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool 2–1 Blackburn |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/9107874.stm |accessdate=12 January 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 October 2010}}</ref>
Shelvey joined Championship club Blackpool on loan on 30 September 2011.<ref>[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,,11669_7211036,00.html "Seasiders land Shelvey"]. Sky Sports. 20 September 2011.</ref> The following day he scored on his debut, in a 5–0 win against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] at [[Bloomfield Road]],<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/15045395.stm "Blackpool 5–0 Bristol City"]. BBC Sport. 1 October 2011.</ref> and also scored his first professional [[hat-trick]] in a 5–0 win away at [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on 3 November.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/15457090.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Leeds 0–5 Blackpool |date=3 November 2011}}</ref>
On 30 November 2011, he was recalled by Liverpool due to injury problems within the team, mainly surrounding [[Steven Gerrard]] and [[Lucas Leiva]], with the latter set to miss the remainder of the season.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~2533307,00.html |title=Shelvey returns to Liverpool |publisher=Blackpool F.C. |accessdate=22 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111202210624/http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10432~2533307,00.html |archivedate=2 December 2011 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He made his first ever Premier League start the following weekend against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref name=lfcfirststart>{{cite news |last=Nursey |first=James |title=Shelvey: Dalglish has saved my Kop career |url=https://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Liverpool-midfielder-Jonjo-Shelvey-grateful-to-Kenny-Dalglish-for-rescuing-his-Kop-career-article844696.html |accessdate=7 January 2012 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |date=19 December 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109231328/http://www.mirrorfootball.co.uk/news/Liverpool-midfielder-Jonjo-Shelvey-grateful-to-Kenny-Dalglish-for-rescuing-his-Kop-career-article844696.html |archive-date=9 January 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 6 January 2012 he scored his first senior goal for the club in a 5–1 win in a third round FA Cup tie against [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] at Anfield,<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool 5 Oldham Athletic 1: match report |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/fa-cup/8999315/Liverpool-5-Oldham-Athletic-1-match-report.html |accessdate=7 January 2012 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=7 January 2012 |location=London |first=Chris |last=Bascombe}}</ref> and on 8 May he scored his first Premier League goal with a 30-yard strike in a 4–1 home win over [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool 4–1 Chelsea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17904221 |accessdate=8 May 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 May 2012}}</ref> He was absent from Liverpool's win over Cardiff City in the season's [[2012 Football League Cup Final|League Cup Final]],<ref>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Bevan |title=Cardiff 2–2 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17093419 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 February 2012 |accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> and was an unused substitute in their loss to Chelsea in the FA Cup equivalent.<ref name=2012FAC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17878435 |title=Chelsea 2–1 Liverpool |first=Phil |last=McNulty |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118044832/https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17878435 |archivedate=18 January 2016}}</ref>
On 10 July 2012, Shelvey signed a new long-term contract with Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/liverpool/9389982/Liverpool-midfielder-Jonjo-Shelvey-signs-new-contract.html |title=Liverpool midfielder Jonjo Shelvey signs new contract |date=10 July 2012 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=10 July 2012 |location=London}}</ref> On 20 September 2012 he came off the bench to score the last 2 goals in a 5–3 win against [[BSC Young Boys|Young Boys]] in the Europa League.<ref>{{cite web |title=Young Boys 3–5 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19582539 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=20 September 2012 |date=20 September 2012}}</ref> Three days later, he was sent off in a league match against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 23 September 2012.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/sep/23/liverpool-manchester-united-match-report |title=Liverpool 1 Man Utd 2 |date=23 September 2012 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=10 October 2012}}</ref> He finished the Europa League group stage with four goals, adding one each in a home defeat to [[Udinese Calcio|Udinese]] on 4 October,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/oct/04/liverpool-udinese-europa-league-match-report |title=Liverpool 2 Udinese 3 |date=4 October 2012 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=10 October 2012}}</ref> and a draw with Young Boys on 22 November.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23143710 |title=Swansea City complete £5m Jonjo Shelvey signing |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=4 July 2013}}</ref>
===Swansea City=== [[File:Jonjo Shelvey 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|Shelvey playing for [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] 2015]]
On 3 July 2013, Shelvey signed a four-year contract with [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], for an initial transfer fee of £5 million.<ref name=SwaTransfer>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23143710 |title=Swansea City complete £5m Jonjo Shelvey signing |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 July 2013 |accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club on 16 September 2013, in a 2–2 draw with former club Liverpool, also assisting teammate [[Michu]]'s goal, but was partly responsible for both Liverpool goals, giving the ball away to [[Daniel Sturridge]] and [[Victor Moses]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24012560 "Swansea 2–2 Liverpool"]. BBC Sport. 16 September 2013. Retrieved 17 September 2013.</ref> He scored a goal on 26 April 2014 in a 4–1 defeat of Aston Villa; from [[Brad Guzan]]'s clearance, Shelvey "controlled the ball with one touch before propelling it over the back-pedalling American's head and into the net."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/swansea-4-aston-villa-1-match-report-jonjo-shelvey-wonder-goal-all-but-secures-swans-premier-league-status-9291624.html |title=Swansea 4 Aston Villa 1 match report: Jonjo Shelvey's superb strike stuns Villa |first=Andrew |last=Gwilym |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=26 April 2014 |accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref>
Shelvey was sent off in a goalless draw at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 1 November 2014, by getting two bookings. First, he kicked the ball away in the 24th minute, then in the 72nd minute, he blocked [[James McCarthy (footballer)|James McCarthy]]'s run, resulting in the second booking.<ref>{{cite news |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Everton 0–0 Swansea |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29768011 |accessdate=2 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 November 2014}}</ref> On 29 December, he caught Liverpool's [[Emre Can]] with his arm during a 4–1 away defeat. Although referee [[Andre Marriner]] did not punish him for it, [[the Football Association]] later gave Shelvey a four-match suspension for violent conduct, with one match having been added to the suspension because of his previous dismissal against Everton. He claimed that the act was unintentional and personally apologised to Can.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey: Swansea midfielder gets four-match ban for Can clash |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30634753 |accessdate=1 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 December 2014}}</ref> The day before the Liverpool match, Swansea manager [[Garry Monk]] criticised Shelvey's disciplinary record, telling him to "wise up" and put a stop to an accumulation of yellow cards earned through "laziness".<ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey: Swansea midfielder must wise up, says Garry Monk |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30620866 |accessdate=1 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2014}}</ref>
In July 2015, Shelvey signed a new, four-year deal with the Swans, which would have kept him at the club until the summer of 2019.<ref>{{cite web |title=Shelvey signs new Swans contract |url=https://www.swanseacity.com/news/article/jonjo-shelvey-signs-new-swansea-city-contract-2533483.aspx |publisher=Swansea City A.F.C. |date=8 July 2015 |accessdate=1 January 2018|}}</ref>
On 10 January 2016, following a shock 3–2 defeat to League Two team [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] in the [[2015–16 FA Cup#Third Round Proper|FA Cup]], Shelvey appeared to become embroiled in a row with one Swansea fan and then appeared to invite the man to meet him outside. Manager [[Alan Curtis (footballer)|Alan Curtis]] responded stating "we expect more from Jonjo, it is as simple as that".<ref>{{cite web |title=Swansea's Jonjo Shelvey in angry confrontation with fan after cup defeat |url=http://www.espnfc.com/swansea-city/story/2784480/swansea-jonjo-shelvey-in-angry-confrontation-with-fan |publisher=ESPN FC |accessdate=12 January 2016 |date=12 January 2016}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== On 12 January 2016, [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] announced they had signed Shelvey on a five-and-a-half-year deal, for a reported fee of £12 million.<ref>{{cite web |title=Newcastle sign Shelvey |url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20160112/newcastle-sign-shelvey_2281670_5268851 |publisher=Newcastle United F.C. |accessdate=12 January 2016 |date=12 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey: Newcastle sign Swansea midfielder for £12m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35290127 |date=12 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Four days later he made his debut in a 2–1 Premier League victory over West Ham United, the first win for the club in seven matches.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey shines in Newcastle debut win but could face FA action |url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/jonjo-shelvey-shines-in-newcastle-debut-win-but-could-face-fa-action-34370240.html |newspaper=Irish Independent |location=Dublin |accessdate=16 January 2016 |date=16 January 2016}}</ref> He was named [[man of the match]] for his involvement in the build-up to both of Newcastle's goals.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey made an impressive debut for Newcastle as he helped his team move out of the relegation zone with a win over West Ham |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/35270693 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=16 January 2016 |date=16 January 2016}}</ref>
While Newcastle were on a training break in [[La Manga]] on 20 February, manager [[Steve McClaren]] announced that Shelvey had been made the team's captain.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gray |first=James |title=Newcastle announce shock new captain |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/645920/Newcastle-Jonjo-Shelvey-captain-Premier-League-news |accessdate=20 February 2016 |newspaper=Daily Express |location=London |date=20 February 2016}}</ref> He served the role as [[Fabricio Coloccini]] stayed out through a calf injury, and said that he wanted to help the club avoid relegation;<ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey: Stand-in Newcastle United captain wants to inspire safety push |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35729286 |accessdate=11 May 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 March 2016}}</ref> they were unsuccessful in that aim.
Shelvey scored his first goal for the club in a 2–0 win against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 27 August 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37138687 |title=Newcastle 2–0 Brighton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 August 2016 |accessdate=29 August 2016}}</ref> In December 2016, Shelvey was banned for five matches after being found guilty of using racially abusive language towards [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] player, [[Romain Saïss]], in a match on 17 September 2016. He was also fined £100,000 and ordered to attend a Football Association education course.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38366883 |title=Jonjo Shelvey: Newcastle United midfielder handed five-game racial abuse ban |date=20 December 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He made 47 appearances and scored 5 goals in [[2016–17 Newcastle United F.C. season|2016–17]]<ref name=sb1617/> as Newcastle were promoted to the Premier League after winning the Championship title.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=1502 |title=Championship: 2016/17: Latest table |website=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=4 June 2017}}</ref>
Ahead of the new season, Shelvey changed his squad number from 12 to 8. On 13 August 2017, in Newcastle United's first match back in the Premier League against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], Shelvey was sent off three minutes into the second half of the match, for stamping on Tottenham midfielder [[Dele Alli]]. Newcastle would go on to lose the match 2–0, with Shelvey later apologising for his violent conduct.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/10987259/jonjo-shelvey-has-apologised-for-red-card-says-rafa-benitez |title=Jonjo Shelvey has apologised for red card, says Rafa Benitez |publisher=Sky Sports |date=13 August 2017}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Jonjo Shelvey and Jordan Henderson.jpg|thumb|upright|Shelvey (left) playing for [[England national under-21 football team|England U21s]] in 2012]]
===Youth=== Shelvey captained the [[England national under-16 football team|England under-16s]] as they won the [[2007 Victory Shield]] scoring three goals in three matches. He played a key role in the Montaigu Tournament, which England won for the first time in seven years, playing in all four matches and scoring a free kick in the final against France.{{cn|date=April 2017}} In October 2008, he made his debut for the [[England national under-17 football team|England under-17s]] and scored in a 7–0 win over [[Estonia national youth football team|Estonia]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Lions hit seven |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/Mens-u17s/news/2009/u17s_estonia_report |publisher=The Football Association |date=24 April 2008 |accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref>
On his debut for the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19s]], in September 2010, he captained and scored a free-kick in a 2–0 win over Slovakia,<ref>{{cite news |title=Liverpool lads fire Lions to victory |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/England%20v%20Slovakia |publisher=The Football Association |date=2 September 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2010}}</ref> and followed up by scoring on his following two appearances for the team.<ref>{{cite news |title=Six of the best |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u19s/News/Match%20Centre/England%20v%20Albania |publisher=The Football Association |date=8 October 2010 |accessdate=10 November 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Shelvey on target for England |url=http://www.Liverpool.tv/news/latest-news/shelvey-on-target-for-england |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=10 October 2010 |accessdate=10 October 2010}}</ref> He won his first Under-21 cap coming on as substitute in a 6–0 win against [[Azerbaijan national under-21 football team|Azerbaijan]] in September 2011.<ref name=u21debut>{{cite web |last=Campbell |first=Al |title=Henderson scores for Under 21's |url=http://www.lfconline.com/news/tmnw/henderson_scores_for_under_21s_698655/index.shtml |publisher=lfconline.com |accessdate=7 January 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140506202424/http://www.lfconline.com/news/tmnw/henderson_scores_for_under_21s_698655/index.shtml |archivedate=6 May 2014}}</ref>
England's senior manager [[Roy Hodgson]] claimed that Shelvey missed the [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] because he was "reticent" about playing at that level following his senior international debut. Shelvey responded by saying that he had been told by under-21 manager [[Gareth Southgate]] that he would not feature in that squad, and claimed that if he had ever refused international duty he would have faced the wrath of his father.<ref name=snub>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey denies snubbing England U21 duty |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12016/9976526/jonjo-shelvey-denies-snubbing-england-u21-duty |accessdate=12 January 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 September 2015}}</ref>
===Senior=== Shelvey was eligible to play for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] – through his grandfather – and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]],<ref>[http://sport.stv.tv/football/scottish-premier/dundee-united/278956-craig-levein-wants-liverpool-starlet-to-switch-to-scotland/ "Craig Levein wants Liverpool starlet to switch to Scotland"]. sport.stv.tv. Retrieved 22 August 2015.</ref> but chose to represent England.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.herald.ie/sport/soccer/shelvey-spurns-ireland-despite-promise-of-cap-oshea-happy-at-blues-27928317.html |title=Shelvey spurns Ireland despite promise of cap O'Shea happy at Blues |newspaper=The Herald |location=Dublin |date=9 October 2009 |accessdate=23 January 2018}}</ref> In October 2012 Shelvey was called up for the [[England national football team|England]] squad for two [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification]] matches against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Poland national football team|Poland]],<ref>{{cite web |title=England call-ups for Jonjo Shelvey and Ryan Bertrand |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19860360 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> and made his senior debut from the bench on 12 October 2012, in a 5–0 home win against San Marino, replacing [[Michael Carrick]] in the 66th minute.<ref>{{cite news |title=England 5–0 San Marino |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19860360 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref>
On 5 September 2015, Shelvey was selected to start for England for the first time in a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against San Marino, becoming the first man to be capped for England whilst playing for Swansea City. He was named man of the match by the [[BBC]] as England ran out 6–0 winners in [[Serravalle (San Marino)|Serravalle]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34165282 |title=San Marino v England: How the players rated |date=5 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==Personal life== Shelvey was born in [[Romford]], London<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/jonjo-shelvey-228577/ |title=Jonjo Shelvey |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=14 December 2017}}</ref> and grew up in a council flat in [[Harold Hill]]. Due to crime in the neighbourhood, he bought his sister a home in [[Brentwood, Essex|Brentwood]] when she became pregnant. His older brother George was, according to Shelvey, a better footballer, but his career was ruined by drinking and partying.<ref name=rough>{{cite news |last=James |first=Stuart |title=Jonjo Shelvey: 'Growing up it was rough, people were getting stabbed' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/dec/20/jonjo-shelvey-swansea-city-interview |accessdate=12 January 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=20 December 2013}}</ref>
Shelvey fell down a staircase as a baby, one of several childhood traumas which he believes could have caused the [[alopecia]] which caused his hair loss. He was prescribed a cream and told to sleep in a woolly hat for a month in order to combat it, but abandoned treatment because of the discomfort it caused, and said of his baldness, "If you don't like it, don't talk to me".<ref name=rough/> Shelvey has supported youngsters who share his condition.<ref>{{cite news |last=Richman |first=Darren |title=Swansea's Jonjo Shelvey gives young alopecia sufferer day to remember after receiving heartfelt letter |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/swansea-city/11125000/Swanseas-Jonjo-Shelvey-gives-young-alopecia-sufferer-day-to-remember-after-receiving-heartfelt-letter.html |accessdate=12 January 2016 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=26 September 2014}}</ref>
In June 2015, Shelvey married Daisy Evans, formerly of the pop group [[S Club 8]]. Comedian [[Jimmy Carr]] performed at the event. The couple have a daughter, born the previous year.<ref>{{cite news |title=Jonjo Shelvey marries Daisy Evans in lavish ceremony with helicopter entrance and Jimmy Carr show |url=http://www.southwales-eveningpost.co.uk/Jonjo-Shelvey-marries-Daisy-Evans-lavish-ceremony/story-26743379-detail/story.html |accessdate=12 January 2016 |newspaper=South Wales Evening Post |location=Swansea |date=22 June 2015}}</ref> After his marriage, Shelvey advertised for a live-in chef, who would receive an annual salary of £65,000.<ref>{{cite news |last=Graves |first=Steve |title=Jonjo Shelvey advertises for chef on £65,000 a year |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/jonjo-shelvey-advertises-chef-65000-9657234 |accessdate=12 January 2016 |newspaper=Liverpool Echo |date=14 July 2015}}</ref> He stated that his family responsibilities and new diet would improve his professional behaviour.<ref name=snub/>

{{short description|Venezuelan association football player}} {{for|the baseball player|José Rondón}} {{Spanish name|Rondón|Giménez}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Salomón Rondón | image = SupercupRazdevalka (6).jpg | caption = Rondón holding the [[2015 Russian Super Cup]] with Zenit | fullname = José Salomón Rondón Giménez | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1989|9|16|df=y}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wba.co.uk/team/player-profile/jose-salomon-rondon/33|title=Jose Salomon Rondon|publisher=West Bromwich Albion F.C|accessdate=6 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005819/http://www.wba.co.uk/team/player-profile/jose-salomon-rondon/33|archivedate=5 March 2016}} | birth_place = [[Caracas]], Venezuela | height = 1.86 m | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]
(on loan from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = 1996–2004 | youthclubs1 = San José de Calasanz | youthyears2 = 2004–2005 | youthclubs2 = Deportivo Gulima | youthyears3 = 2005–2006 | youthclubs3 = [[Aragua FC|Aragua]] | years1 = 2006–2008 | clubs1 = [[Aragua FC|Aragua]] | caps1 = 49 | goals1 = 15 | years2 = 2008–2010 | clubs2 = [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]] | caps2 = 46 | goals2 = 10 | years3 = 2010–2012 | clubs3 = [[Málaga CF|Málaga]] | caps3 = 67 | goals3 = 25 | years4 = 2012–2014 | clubs4 = [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]] | caps4 = 36 | goals4 = 13 | years5 = 2014–2015 | clubs5 = [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] | caps5 = 37 | goals5 = 20 | years6 = 2015– | clubs6 = [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] | caps6 = 108 | goals6 = 24 | years7 = 2018– | clubs7 = → [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] (loan) | caps7 = 25 | goals7 = 9 | nationalyears1 = 2009 | nationalteam1 = [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 11 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | nationalyears2 = 2008– | nationalteam2 = [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] | nationalcaps2 = 70 | nationalgoals2 = 21 | club-update = 17:29, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:16, 20 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''José Salomón Rondón Giménez''' ({{IPA-es|saloˈmon ronˈdon}}; born 16 September 1989) is a Venezuelan professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for English club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on loan from [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], and the [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela national team]]. After starting out at [[Aragua FC|Aragua]], he went on to spend most of his career in Europe, appearing in [[La Liga]] with [[Málaga CF|Málaga]], the [[Russian Premier League]] with [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]] and [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit Saint Petersburg]] (winning the [[2014–15 Russian Premier League|2015 national championship]] with the latter club) and the [[Premier League]] with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. A [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela international]] since 2008, Rondón represented his country in three [[Copa América]] tournaments. ==Club career== ===Early years=== Born in [[Caracas]], Rondón's sporting idols growing up were [[Ronaldo (Brazilian footballer)|Ronaldo]] and [[Michael Jordan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/club/brazil/205/blog/post/2840087/ronaldo-deserves-more-credit-as-one-of-the-games-best|title=Ronaldo deserves more credit as one of the game's greatest players|publisher=[[ESPN]]|last1=Smith|first1=Rory|date=30 March 2016|accessdate=25 August 2018}} He made his debut in the [[Venezuelan Primera División]] at the age of 17, appearing for [[Aragua FC]] against [[Carabobo FC]] on 8 October 2006; on 8 April of the following year he scored his first goal(s) for the club, in a 2–2 draw against [[Caracas FC]]. ===Las Palmas=== In the summer of 2008, Rondón was signed by [[UD Las Palmas]] in Spain, and made his official debut on 5 October in a 1–2 away loss against [[Deportivo Alavés]] for the [[Segunda División]] championship.{{cite news|url=http://archivo.marca.com/edicion/marca/futbol/2a_division/cronica/es/desarrollo/1172328.html|title=El Alavés remontó con toda justicia en Mendizorroza|trans-title=Alavés came back from behind in Mendizorroza justly|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=es|date=5 October 2008|accessdate=9 April 2014}} Almost one year after his arrival, on 2 September 2009, he netted his first goal, in a [[Copa del Rey]] [[2009–10 Copa del Rey|match]] against [[Cádiz CF]] – becoming the youngest foreign player to ever score for the club, at the age of 19 years, 11 months and 17 days{{cite news|url=http://www.laprovincia.es/deportes/2009/09/04/gol-extranjero-joven/255281.html|title=El gol extranjero más joven|trans-title=Youngest foreign goal|newspaper=La Provincia|language=es|date=4 September 2009|accessdate=24 November 2010}}– and finished [[2009–10 Segunda División|the season]] with ten goals in 36 games, as the [[Canary Islands]] side narrowly avoided relegation.{{cite news|url=http://www.laopiniondemalaga.es/malagacf/2011/02/20/rondon-anatomia-goleador/402699.html|title=Rondón: anatomía de un goleador|trans-title=Rondón: anatomy of a scorer|newspaper=La Opinión de Málaga|language=es|date=17 February 2011|accessdate=11 January 2018}} ===Málaga=== [[File:Salomon rondon malaga caracas.jpg|thumb|left|Rondón says farewell to [[Málaga CF|Málaga]], a week before joining [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]]]] On 19 July 2010, [[Málaga CF]] signed Rondón for a record [[Euro|€]]3.5 million transfer fee.[http://www.listandalucia.com/news/sport/transfer-record-for-malaga-football-club/ Transfer record for Malaga Football Club]; List Andalucia, 20 July 2010 He scored his first goal for the [[Andalusia]]ns exactly two months later, in a 1–2 home defeat against [[Sevilla FC]] in [[La Liga]].[http://www.goal.com/en/match/48603/malaga-vs-sevilla/report Report: Malaga vs Sevilla]; [[Goal (website)|Goal]], 20 September 2010 Four days later, he opened the score in a 2–0 win at [[Getafe CF]],[http://www.goal.com/en/news/12/spain/2010/09/23/2133624/primera-liga-round-up-sevilla-held-at-home-malaga-stun Primera Liga round-up: Sevilla held at home, Malaga stun Getafe, Villarreal edge past Deportivo La Coruna]; Goal, 23 September 2010 adding a third the following week in a 2–3 home loss to [[Villarreal CF]].[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=302129&campaign=rss&source=soccernet&cc=3888 First-half thriller]; [[ESPN FC|ESPN Soccernet]], 27 September 2010 On 1 May 2011, Rondón contributed with one goal as Málaga came from behind at home to defeat [[Hércules CF]] 3–1.[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=301948&cc=5739 The Beast boosts Malaga hopes]; ESPN Soccernet, 1 May 2011 That was his 13th goal of [[2010–11 La Liga|the campaign]], with which he surpassed the record of goals from a Venezuelan footballer in the Spanish top flight previously held by [[Juan Arango]];{{cite news|url=http://eltiempo.com.ve/deportes/futbol/salomon-rondon-anoto-e-hizo-historia/20166|title=Salomón Rondón anotó e hizo historia|trans-title=Salomón Rondón scored and made history|newspaper=[[El Tiempo (Anzoátegui)|El Tiempo]]|language=es|date=2 May 2011|accessdate=2 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110504085755/http://eltiempo.com.ve/deportes/futbol/salomon-rondon-anoto-e-hizo-historia/20166|archivedate=4 May 2011|df=}} the team finally escaped relegation, with the player finishing as their top scorer.{{cite web|url=http://malaga.eldesmarque.com/malaga-cf/52060-sandro-y-el-exclusivo-club-de-los-10|title=Sandro y el exclusivo club de los 10|trans-title=Sandro and the exclusive 10 club|publisher=El Desmarque|language=es|date=20 April 2017|accessdate=11 January 2018}} Rondón started [[2011–12 La Liga|2011–12]] on the [[Substitute (association football)|substitutes]] bench. He eventually beat competition from ageing [[Ruud van Nistelrooy]],{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2012/05/18/futbol/equipos/malaga/1337360836.html|title=Rondón, "orgulloso y encantado" de haber aprendido de Van Nistelrooy|trans-title=Rondón, "proud and delighted" for having learned from Van Nistelrooy|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=18 May 2012|accessdate=9 April 2014}} again finishing as Málaga's best scorer – this included goals in narrow home wins against [[RCD Espanyol]] (2–1)[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=323932&cc=5739 Malaga end losing run]; ESPN Soccernet, 30 October 2011 and [[Levante UD]] (1–0),[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=323790&cc=5739 Rondon boosts Boquerones]; ESPN Soccernet, 10 March 2012 and a brace against [[Rayo Vallecano]] (4–2 success, also at [[La Rosaleda Stadium]]).[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=323774&cc=5739 Rondon doubles up in Malaga win]; ESPN Soccernet, 22 March 2012 ===Rubin Kazan=== [[File:Соломон Рондон.jpg|190px|thumb|Rondón before a [[2012-13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] match against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]]] In August 2012, Rondón signed for [[Russian Premier League]] team [[FC Rubin Kazan]], for a reported fee of €10 million[http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=1845061.html Rubin lure Rondón from Málaga]; UEFA, 5 August 2012 which made him the most expensive Venezuelan player in history.{{cite news|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ve/deportes/salomon-rondon-es-el-futbolista-venezolano-mas-caro-de-la-historia/|title=Salomón Rondón es el futbolista venezolano más caro de la historia|trans-title=Salomón Rondón is Venezuela's most expensive footballer in history|newspaper=La Nación|language=es|date=6 August 2012|accessdate=22 September 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120809214351/http://www.lanacion.com.ve/deportes/salomon-rondon-es-el-futbolista-venezolano-mas-caro-de-la-historia/|archivedate=9 August 2012|df=}} He made his [[2012–13 Russian Premier League|league]] debut on the 12th in a 2–0 home win over [[FC Dynamo Moscow]], and he scored his first goal against [[FC Terek Grozny]] on 1 September, albeit in a 1–2 home defeat.[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match?id=342386&cc=3888 FK Rubin Kazan 1–2 Terek Grozny]; ESPN Soccernet, 1 September 2012 Rondón made his first appearance in the [[UEFA Europa League]] against [[Inter Milan]], and he scored once in a [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League group stage|2–2 group stage away draw]], also playing the entire match.[http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000356/match=2009905/postmatch/report/index.html Nagatomo salvages Inter draw against Rubin]; UEFA, 20 September 2012 In the second match between the two sides he netted a brace in the final three minutes, helping his team to a 3–0 win.{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/355848/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=FK Rubin Kazan 3–0 Internazionale|publisher=ESPN FC|date=22 November 2012|accessdate=22 November 2012}} On 10 March 2013, following the winter break in the Russian Premier League, Rondón scored the only goal of the match as Rubin claimed a home victory over reigning champions [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]].{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/gamecast/statistics/id/363310/statistics.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=FK Rubin Kazan 1–0 Zenit St. Petersburg|publisher=ESPN FC|date=10 March 2013|accessdate=14 March 2013}} In [[UEFA|continental competition]], he opened up the scoring in the 100th minute of the [[Single-elimination tournament|round-of-16]] clash against Levante, latching on to a cross from [[Bibras Natkho]] as the hosts won it 2–0 in that leg and on aggregate.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000358/match=2010080/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Rubin edge out Levante in extra time|publisher=UEFA|date=14 March 2013|accessdate=14 March 2013}} On 19 April 2013, Rondón opened the scoring for Rubin, who could only manage a 1–1 draw at relegation-threatened [[FC Amkar Perm]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/04/19/russia/premier-league/fk-amkar-perm/rubin-kazan/1287072/|title=Amkar Perm 1–1 Rubin Kazan|publisher=Soccerway|date=19 April 2013}} In the club's next league match, against [[PFC CSKA Moscow]], he netted the first goal in a 2–0 victory over the league leaders and eventual champions.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/04/28/russia/premier-league/rubin-kazan/cska-moskva/1287076/|title=Rubin Kazan 2–0 CSKA Moskva|publisher=Soccerway|date=28 April 2013}} On 1 September 2013, Rondón scored a [[hat-trick]] in a 3–0 win against recently promoted [[FC Ural Sverdlovsk Oblast]].{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/gamecast/statistics/id/380600/statistics.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=Ural 0–3 FK Rubin Kazan|publisher=ESPN FC|date=1 September 2013 |accessdate=1 September 2013}} ===Zenit=== On 31 January 2014, Rondón underwent a medical and joined fellow league club Zenit Saint Petersburg, signing a five-year contract for a fee in the region of £15.8 million.{{cite web|url=http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/ct3/58191.html|title=Zenit signs Salomón Rondón|publisher=FC Zenit|date=31 January 2014|accessdate=31 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202100053/http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/ct3/58191.html|archivedate= 2 February 2014|df=}} He played his first game for his new team on 25 February, scoring in an eventual [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|2–1 away win]] against [[Borussia Dortmund]] in the [[UEFA Champions League]]'s round of 16-second-leg (4–5 aggregate defeat).{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26620485|title=Borussia Dortmund 1–2 Zenit St Petersburg|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 February 2014|accessdate=19 March 2014}} On 6 April 2014, again as a second-half substitute, Rondón scored a rare second-half hat-trick in a 6–2 home routing of former team Rubin.{{cite web|url=http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/team/58469.html|title=Rondon hat-trick rocks Rubin|publisher=FC Zenit|date=6 April 2014|accessdate=9 April 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140409095716/http://en.fc-zenit.ru/main/news/team/58469.html|archivedate=9 April 2014}} On 20 September he added another three, in a 5–0 win at [[FC Rostov]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/gamecast/statistics/id/397886/statistics.html|title=Rostov 0–5 Zenit St Petersburg|publisher=ESPN FC|date=20 September 2014|accessdate=20 September 2014}} On 26 February 2015, Rondón scored a brace at home against [[PSV Eindhoven]], being essential in a 3–0 home victory for the [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|Europa League round-of-32]] and a 4–0 aggregate triumph.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uefa-europa-league/match/410561/zenit-st-petersburg-psv-eindhoven/report|title=Zenit St Petersburg 3–0 PSV Eindhoven|publisher=ESPN FC|date=26 February 2015|accessdate=28 December 2015}} ===West Bromwich Albion=== [[File:SRondon West Brom.jpg|alt=|thumb|Rondón ''(left)'' playing for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in 2017]] On 10 August 2015, Rondón joined English club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on a four-year-deal for a club-record fee of £12 million.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33852895|title=Salomon Rondon: West Brom sign striker for club record £12m|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 August 2015|accessdate=10 August 2015}} He made his debut in the [[Premier League]] five days later, replacing [[Craig Gardner]] in the 62nd minute of an eventual 0–0 away draw against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/barclays-premier-league/match/422654/watford-west-bromwich-albion/report|title=Watford frustrated as West Bromwich Albion share spoils at Vicarage Road|publisher=ESPN FC|date=15 August 2015|accessdate=15 August 2015}} On the 23rd he made his first start, at the expense of [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]-linked [[Saido Berahino]], in a 2–3 home defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Assist (football)|assisting]] [[James Morrison (footballer)|James Morrison]] in his first goal and later being brought down by [[John Terry]] who received a straight [[Ejection (sports)|red card]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33950789|title=West Bromwich Albion 2–3 Chelsea|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Magowan|first=Alistair|date=23 August 2015|accessdate=23 August 2015}} Rondón scored his first goal for the Baggies on 29 August 2015, netting the game's only in stoppage time of the first half of the away fixture against nine-man [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34025390|title=Stoke City 0–1 West Bromwich Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2015|accessdate=29 August 2015}} On 19 December, he was sent off at the end of a 1–2 home loss to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for thrusting his head at [[Dan Gosling]], with teammate [[James McClean]] also dismissed in the first half;{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35078556|title=West Bromwich Albion 1–2 Bournemouth|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Chowdhury|first=Saj|date=19 December 2015|accessdate=19 December 2015}} he finished [[2015–16 Premier League|his first season]] in English football with ten goals.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240499|title=West Bromwich Albion 1–1 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 May 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} Rondón began the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17 campaign]] strongly, scoring the winner goal on the opening match victory against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], then continued his impressive form in September with goals in consecutive matches against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37325836|title=West Bromwich Albion 4–2 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 September 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} and Stoke.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37393497|title=Stoke City 1–1 West Bromwich Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 September 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} On 21 November he netted once and provided an assist in a 4–0 victory over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37970618|title=West Bromwich Albion 4–0 Burnley|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 November 2016|accessdate=22 November 2016}} and on 14 December, against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], he scored his first Premier League hat-trick after netting three headers in a 3–1 win, which was only the second time this feat was achieved in the history of the competition, the first being [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]'s [[Duncan Ferguson]] in 1997.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38232131|title=West Bromwich Albion 3–1 Swansea City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 December 2016|accessdate=15 December 2016}} Rondón's goal in 1–1 draw with Tottenham, on 25 November 2017, made him the first Venezuelan to score at either the rebuilt [[Wembley Stadium]] or the [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|original facilities]],{{cite news|url=http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/sport/national/15684989.Alan_Pardew_reveals_talks_with_West_Brom_over_manager___s_job/|title=Alan Pardew reveals talks with West Brom over manager's job|newspaper=[[The Westmorland Gazette]]|date=26 November 2017|accessdate=9 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171209194851/http://www.thewestmorlandgazette.co.uk/sport/national/15684989.Alan_Pardew_reveals_talks_with_West_Brom_over_manager___s_job/|archive-date=9 December 2017|dead-url=no}} as well as the first Albion player to score at the new ground. The following 20 January, early into the second half of the away fixture against Everton, he accidentally broke [[James McCarthy (footballer)|James McCarthy]]'s leg, being reduced to tears after realising the outcome.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/irelands-james-mccarthy-suffers-horrific-double-leg-break-that-left-opponent-in-tears-36511159.html|title=Ireland's James McCarthy suffers horrific double leg break that left opponent in tears|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|date=20 January 2018|accessdate=20 January 2018}} ===Newcastle United=== On 6 August 2018, Rondón joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on a one-year loan deal, with [[Dwight Gayle]] heading in the opposite direction in the same situation.{{Cite web|url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/latest-news/magpies-complete-rondon-loan-signing|title=Magpies complete Rondón loan signing|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|date=6 August 2018|accessdate=6 August 2018}} He made his debut five days later, in a 2–1 home loss against Tottenham on the opening day of [[2018–19 Premier League|the season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45067372|title=Alli helps Tottenham to a 2–1 win over Newcastle|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Sutcliffe|first=Steve|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=17 October 2018}} He scored his first goal in a [[EFL Cup]] defeat by [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on 29 August, with a late equaliser that failed to prevent his team's elimination in [[2018–19 EFL Cup|the second round]] (3–1 defeat at [[City Ground]]).{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45266833|title=Nottingham Forest 3–1 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2018|accessdate=17 October 2018}} Rondón opened his league account on 10 November 2018, scoring twice to help the hosts defeat Bournemouth 2–1.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46081229|title=Newcastle United 2–1 AFC Bournemouth|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Poole|first=Harry|date=10 November 2018|accessdate=14 November 2018}} ==International career== Rondón appeared for the [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela under-20 side]] in the [[2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2009 FIFA World Cup]] in Egypt. He scored four times during the competition – as teammate Yonathan del Valle, with both netting [[hat-trick]]s in the 8–0 group stage routing of [[Tahiti national football team|Tahiti]] – as the former managed to qualify to the [[Single-elimination tournament|last-16 stage]].{{FIFA player|305416}} Previously, on 3 February 2008, 18-year-old Rondón made his debut for [[Venezuela national football team|the senior team]] in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Haiti national football team|Haiti]], scoring his first goal on 23 March against [[El Salvador national football team|El Salvador]] (another exhibition match, another 1–0 win). Selected by manager [[Noel Sanvicente]] to the [[2015 Copa América]], he scored in ''La Vinotinto'''s first game of the tournament to help defeat [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] 1–0;{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jun/14/venezuela-beat-colombia-copa-america-shock|title=Venezuela beat Colombia to cause major Copa América shock|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=14 June 2015|accessdate=15 June 2015}} later that year, he was among 15 national players who threatened to quit the team after the president of the [[Venezuelan Football Federation]] accused them of conspiring to get the manager sacked.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34975551|title=Venezuela: Salomon Rondon and squad in quit threat to board|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 December 2015|accessdate=1 December 2015}} On 5 June 2016, during the [[Copa América Centenario]], Rondón earned his 50th [[Cap (sport)|cap]], starting in a 1–0 group stage win against [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] in [[Chicago]].{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2016/copa_america/1a_fase/jornada_1/grupo_c/jam_ven/|title=Una Jamaica con diez hace sufrir a Venezuela|trans-title=Ten-man Jamaica make Venezuela suffer|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=6 June 2016|accessdate=6 June 2016}} He scored the only goal of the following game against [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] to become the first Venezuelan player to find the net at three tournaments,{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/west-brom-striker-salomon-rondon-11452812|title=West Brom striker Salomon Rondon makes history as Luis Suarez goes into meltdown|newspaper=[[Birmingham Mail]]|date=10 June 2016|accessdate=9 December 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170406052552/http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/west-brom-striker-salomon-rondon-11452812|archive-date=6 April 2017|dead-url=no}} and repeated the feat in the quarter-finals, a 1–4 defeat to [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]].{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/deportes/2016/06/19/5765f0e0268e3ed7118b4657.html|title=Messi e Higuaín liquidan a Venezuela y meten a Argentina en semi-finales|trans-title=Messi and Higuaín kill Venezuela and put Argentina in semi-finals|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|language=es|date=19 June 2016|accessdate=11 January 2018}} ==Career statistics== [[File:SupercupRazdevalka |nationalteam2 = [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] |nationalcaps2 = 31 |nationalgoals2 = 1 |club-update = 16:55, 16 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 08:19, 14 January 2018 (UTC) }} '''Mohamed Diamé''' (born 14 June 1987), also known as '''Momo Diamé''',<ref name="Momo">{{cite news|url=http://www.afrikansoccer.com/2011/05/sevilla-track-senegal-midfielder-momo-diame/|title=Sevilla track Senegal midfielder Momo Diame|accessdate=21 May 2011|date=18 May 2011|publisher=Afrikan Soccer|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606032345/http://www.afrikansoccer.com/2011/05/sevilla-track-senegal-midfielder-momo-diame/|archivedate=6 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for English club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].
Though born in France, Diamé represented [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] at international level and made 31 appearances before retiring from national duty in 2017.
==Club career== ===Early career=== Diamé was born in the Paris suburb of [[Créteil]] and he was selected to attend the [[INF Clairefontaine|Clairefontaine academy]] between 2000 and 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.fff.fr/presentationfff/actualite/418646.shtml |title=INF, formateur de talents |accessdate=29 December 2012 |publisher=French Football Federationd |language=French |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114014916/http://www.fff.fr/presentationfff/actualite/418646.shtml |archivedate=14 November 2012 |df= }}</ref> Diamé began his professional career in 2003 with [[RC Lens]], but left four years later after facing health problems.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://descubrepromesas.blogspot.com/2008/09/mohamed-diame.html|title=Profile|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=21 September 2008|language=Spanish|publisher=descubrepromesas}}</ref> After a full recovery, he signed for lowly Spanish side [[CD Linares]] in 30 July 2007,<ref>{{cite web|last1=García Caño|first1=Pablo|title=Diame convence a Braojos y se queda en el CD Linares|url=http://www.ideal.es/jaen/prensa/20070731/deportes_jaen/diame-convence-braojos-queda_20070731.html|website=Ideal|accessdate=3 August 2016|language=Spanish|date=31 July 2007}}</ref> and moved to [[Rayo Vallecano]] the following year,<ref>{{cite web|author1=Agencia EFE|authorlink1=Agencia EFE|title=Diamé ficha por el Rayo Vallecano|url=http://www.lavozdigital.es/cadiz/20080621/deportes/mas-futbol/diame-ficha-rayo-vallecano-20080621.html|website=La Voz Digital|accessdate=3 August 2016|language=Spanish|date=21 January 2008}}</ref> helping the [[Madrid]]-based team to a [[2008–09 Segunda División|mid-table position]] in the [[Segunda División]], after being promoted in the [[2007–08 Segunda División B|2007–08 season]]. During his time with Rayo it was reported that [[La Liga]] giants [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] were interested in signing the midfielder,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/barcelona-real-madrid-battle-rayo-vallecano-star-mohamed-diame-217692|title=Barcelona, Real Madrid battle for Rayo Vallecano star Mohamed Diame|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=21 December 2008|publisher=Tribal Football}}</ref> as well as [[Premier League]] side [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.imscouting.com/global-news-article/the-lowdown-on-arsenal-target-mohamed-diame/1159/|title=The lowdown on Arsenal target Mohamed Diame|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=25 January 2009|publisher=IMScouting}}</ref>
===Wigan Athletic=== On 22 August 2009, Diamé joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/wigan_athletic/8205476.stm|title=Wigan complete capture of Diame|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=22 August 2009|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> The transfer had earlier been temporarily put on hold, after alleged heart problems were found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2009/08/14/futbol/equipos/rayo/1250232313.html|title=El corazón de Diamé frena su fichaje por el Wigan|trans-title=Diamé's heart halts signing with Wigan|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=14 August 2009|author=Froilán Mora|language=Spanish|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid}}</ref> Diamé made his debut the same day as his transfer, in a 5–0 defeat to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8209298.stm|title=Wigan 0–5 Man Utd|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=22 August 2009|author=Chris Bevan|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Wigan against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 6 February 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8493730.stm|title=Sunderland 1–1 Wigan|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=6 February 2010|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> At the end of the 2011–12 season, he left Wigan after declining their offer to extend his contract.<ref name=Bosman>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Simon|title=Liverpool and Spurs lead chase for Diame with midfielder set to leave Wigan for free|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2144709/Mohamed-Diame-leave-Wigan-Athletic.html|accessdate=13 June 2012|newspaper=Daily Mail|location=London|date=15 May 2012}}</ref>
===West Ham United=== On 20 June 2012, Diamé joined [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120620/diame-deal-agreed_2236884_2817081|title=Diame deal agreed|date=20 June 2012|publisher=West Ham United F.C.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120622055808/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120620/diame-deal-agreed_2236884_2817081|archivedate=22 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18521050|title=Mohamed Diame to join West Ham from Wigan on a three-year deal|date=20 June 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Diamé made his debut for West Ham on 18 August 2012 in a 1–0 win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=West Ham 1–0 Aston Vila|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19221467|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 August 2012}}</ref> He scored his first goal for West Ham United in the 3–1 defeat to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 6 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19768703|title=West Ham 1–3 Arsenal|date=6 October 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> His second goal for the club was scored in the 3–1 victory over [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 1 December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20474474|title=West Ham 3–1 Chelsea|date=1 December 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 9 December 2012, Diamé was injured in a match against Liverpool; it was initially thought he could be out for up to 3 months.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20661134|title=West Ham: Hamstring tear to sideline Mohamed Diame|date=9 December 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> In January 2013, after a number of clubs were purported to be interested in signing him, Diamé stated that he wished to stay with West Ham.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21182797|title=Mohamed Diame 'very happy' at West Ham despite Arsenal link|date=24 January 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jan/24/tottenham-mohamed-diame-west-ham|title=Tottenham aim to tempt Mohamed Diamé from West Ham for £3.5m|date=24 January 2013|author=David Hytner|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London}}</ref> Diamé did not leave the club in the transfer window, and manager [[Sam Allardyce]] stated that it was an important decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21299380|title=West Ham: It was vital Mohamed Diame stayed – Sam Allardyce|date=1 February 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
===Hull City=== [[File:Mohamed Diame Hull City 2014.jpg|thumb|200px|Diame playing for [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] in 2014 against Everton]] On 1 September 2014, Diamé joined [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-diame-signing-1891684.aspx|title=Tigers Sign Mohamed Diame From West Ham|date=1 September 2014|accessdate=1 September 2014|publisher=Hull City A.F.C.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903142317/http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/1415-diame-signing-1891684.aspx|archivedate=3 September 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Two weeks later, he made his debut at the [[KC Stadium]], scoring against his former club West Ham in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hull City 2–2 West Ham United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29105375|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=15 September 2014|date=15 September 2014}}</ref>
On 28 May 2016, Diamé scored in the [[2016 Football League Championship play-off Final|Championship play-off final]] in a 1–0 win against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], giving Hull an immediate return to the [[Premier League]] after their relegation in the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36348885|title=Hull City 1–0 Sheffield Wednesday|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 May 2016|date=28 May 2016}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== On 3 August 2016, Diamé joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], signing a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/aug/03/newcastle-sign-mohame-diame-hull-city|title=Newcastle sign Mohamed Diamé from Hull City on a three-year contract|work=The Guardian|date=3 August 2016}}</ref> Diamé scored his first goals for Newcastle when he scored twice in an [[EFL Cup]] win against [[Preston North End]] on 25 October 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37686639|title=Newcastle 6–0 Preston North End|publisher=BBC|date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref>
In October 2017 he had a training ground fight with teammate [[Jamaal Lascelles]]. The two players later apologised and offered to take the entire first team squad and staff out for lunch.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/10/13/newcastle-pair-say-sorry-training-ground-fight-offer-whole-squad/|title=Newcastle pair say sorry for training-ground fight and offer whole squad a free lunch|date=2017-10-13|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref>
==International career== On 22 March 2011, Diamé was called up to play for [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]], for whom he qualifies as his father was born in [[Dakar]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2322156,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805212637/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2322156,00.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 August 2012|title=International Rescue!|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=22 March 2011|publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C.}}</ref> Diamé made his international debut later that month.<ref name=NFT>{{NFT player|pid=42803|accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref>
In July 2012, Diamé was announced as one of three over-age players in Senegal's squad for the 2012 Olympics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18754732|title=Senegal leave Papiss Cisse out of Olympic squad|date=7 June 2012|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> He scored his first international goal for Senegal on 26 March 2016 in a 2–0 win against Niger in a [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations qualification]] match.<ref name = "Goal">{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/03/26/africa/africa-cup-of-nations-qualification/senegal/niger/2038151 |title=Senegal vs. Niger 2–0|work=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref>
He retired from international football in March 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39256494|title=Mohamed Diame moves aside for new Senegal stars|date=13 March 2017|accessdate=13 March 2017|author=Oluwashina Okeleji|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
==Personal life== Diamé is Muslim.<ref>{{cite news|last=Din|first=Tusdiq|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/fasting-and-football-how-do-topflight-muslims-cope-2342187.html|title=Fasting and football. How do top-flight Muslims cope? |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |date=23 August 2011|accessdate=10 July 2013}}</ref>
==Career statistics== [[File:Mohamed Diamé.jpg|thumb|200px|Diame playing for [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in 2010.]]
