Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] in 2015 | fullname = Matthew Thomas Ritchie<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|9|10|df=y}}<ref name="Premier League">{{cite web |url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/profile.html/matt-ritchie |title=Premier League Player Profile Matt Ritchie |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2016 |publisher=Barclays Premier League |accessdate=3 February 2016}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Gosport]], England | height = {{convert|1.73|m|order=flip}}<ref name="Premier League"/> | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubnumber = 11 | youthyears1 = 2002–2008 | youthclubs1 = [[Portsmouth F.C. Reserves and Academy|Portsmouth]] | years1 = 2008–2011 | clubs1 = [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] | caps1 = 7 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2008–2009 | clubs2 = → [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] (loan) | caps2 = 37 | goals2 = 11 | years3 = 2009–2010 | clubs3 = → [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] (loan) | caps3 = 16 | goals3 = 3 | years4 = 2010–2011 | clubs4 = → [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] (loan) | caps4 = 16 | goals4 = 3 | years5 = 2011–2013 | clubs5 = [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] | caps5 = 91 | goals5 = 23 | years6 = 2013–2016 | clubs6 = [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] | caps6 = 130 | goals6 = 31 | years7 = 2016– | clubs7 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps7 = 106 | goals7 = 17 | nationalyears1 = 2015– | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] | nationalcaps1 = 16 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | club-update = 17:24, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 22:53, 16 May 2018 (UTC) }} '''Matthew Thomas Ritchie''' (born 10 September 1989) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland national team]]. He previously played for [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] and [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]]. He joined Newcastle United in 2016.
Born and raised in England, Ritchie qualified to play for [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] through his Scottish father. He made his senior international debut on 25 March 2015, in a friendly match against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]].
==Club career== ===Portsmouth=== Ritchie had been involved in Portsmouth's academy since he turned 13, previously playing football locally in Gosport, starting at the age of six.<ref name="Ritchie in dream land">{{cite news|title=Ritchie in dream land|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/ritchie-in-dream-land-1-1299296|publisher=Portsmouth News|date=13 August 2008|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> After signing his first professional contract with the club,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.portsmouthfc.co.uk/index.php?cms_ref=news&qs_article_id=1315 |title=Portsmouth Football Club :: News |publisher=Portsmouthfc.co.uk |date=1 July 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728052519/http://www.portsmouthfc.co.uk/index.php?cms_ref=news&qs_article_id=1315 |archivedate=28 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and a positive 2008–09 pre-season campaign, including a [[hat-trick]] in a 4–1 victory over hometown club [[Gosport Borough F.C.|Gosport Borough]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_3967462,00.html |title=Sky Sports | Football | News | Pompey see off Gosport |publisher=Skysports.com |date= |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref> after the match, Ritchie said scoring a hat-trick was 'unreal'.<ref name="Ritchie in dream land"/>
He went on loan to Swindon Town in 2010 but due to Portsmouth's mounting injury list, he was recalled in March and was named on the bench for their 2–0 [[Premier League]] loss at the hands of [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] after making four appearances for Swindon. On 14 April, he made his League debut for Portsmouth in the game against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]]. He played 79 minutes but was then substituted for [[Frédéric Piquionne]]. After the match, Ritchie admits making his Portsmouth debut was a dream come true.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ritchie: It was a dream come true|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/ritchie-it-was-a-dream-come-true-1-1249529|publisher=Portsmouth News|date=15 February 2010|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> At the end of the season, with Portsmouth's relegation from the Premier League confirmed, he signed a new two-year deal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ritchie set for Pompey stay|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/6221148/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=22 June 2010|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
For the [[2010–11 Football League|2010–11]] season, Ritchie was handed the number 5 shirt and was selected in Portsmouth's starting XI for their first match of the season at [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8881422.stm|title=BBC Sport – Football – Coventry 2–0 Portsmouth|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> However, he soon found himself out of the Portsmouth line-up and, with the club having disbanded its reserve team, manager [[Steve Cotterill]] agreed to loan out the player for fitness reasons.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/frattonlatest/Cotterill-Ritchie-has-a-Blues.6574341.jp|title=Cotterill: Ritchie has a Blues future|website=www.portsmouth.co.uk}}</ref>
====Loan to Dagenham & Redbridge==== Ritchie played reserve and academy football at Pompey until late September and continued to impress until he was taken on a one-month loan deal by [[Football League Two|League Two]] club [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/dagenham_and_redbridge/7636244.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Football | My Club | Dagenham & Redbridge | Daggers bring in Ritchie on loan |publisher=News.bbc.co.uk |date=25 September 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref> He made his Football League debut against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] on 27 September 2008, coming on as a late substitute.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/7626803.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Football | League Two | Dag & Red 1–1 Rotherham |publisher=News.bbc.co.uk |date=27 September 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref> Ritchie scored on his first competitive start for the ''Daggers'' in a 2–0 win over [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/7639346.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Football | League Two | Rochdale 0–2 Dag & Red |publisher=News.bbc.co.uk |date=4 October 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref> He scored again in his next match, a 2–0 win over [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/7646415.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Football | League Two | Dag & Red 2–0 Barnet |publisher=News.bbc.co.uk |date=10 October 2008 |accessdate=2 November 2008}}</ref>
Ritchie also made clear his wishes to extend the loan deal until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teamtalk.com/football/story/0,16368,1782_4344933,00.html |title=Daggers boss keen on Ritchie stay |publisher=Teamtalk.com |date= |accessdate=2 November 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081021174750/http://www.teamtalk.com/football/story/0%2C16368%2C1782_4344933%2C00.html |archivedate=21 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Dagenham announced on 30 December that the player would remain with the club until the end of the current season.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/d/dagenham_and_redbridge/7804737.stm | work=BBC News | title=Daggers extend Ritchie loan spell | date=30 December 2008 | accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref> His impressive performances saw him rewarded with a new two-year deal at Portsmouth,<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11674_5262599,00.html | work=Sky Sports | title=Pompey offer Ritchie new deal | date=1 May 2009}}</ref> and their Young Player of the Season Award.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hat-trick of honours for Johnson|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/hat-trick-of-honours-for-johnson-1-1232220|publisher=Portsmouth News|date=20 May 2009|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
====Loan to Notts County==== On 28 July 2009, it was reported that [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], were in talks with [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] over a six-figure fee for his services, believed to be £100,000.<ref>{{cite news|title=Magpies plan Ritchie raid|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11661/5459759/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=29 July 2009|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> On 1 September 2009, Ritchie signed on loan until 31 December,<ref>{{cite news|title=Magpies swoop for Ritchie|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/5530180/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=1 September 2009|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> although County wanted to extend his loan deal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ritchie wants Magpies stay|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/5700069/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=17 November 2009|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
===Loan to Swindon and permanent basis=== After [[Danny Wilson (footballer, born 1960)|Danny Wilson]] failed to secure Ritchie's services on a permanent deal during the transfer window, it was announced on 11 February 2010 that [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] had signed the midfielder on loan for the remainder of the [[2009–10 in English football|season]].<ref>[http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/headlines/5001709.BREAKING_NEWS__Town_land_Ritchie/ Town land Ritchie] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213213509/http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/headlines/5001709.BREAKING_NEWS__Town_land_Ritchie/ |date=13 February 2010 }}</ref> He made his debut on 23 February against [[Stockport County F.C.|Stockport County]] after coming on for [[Danny Ward (English footballer)|Danny Ward]] after 25 minutes.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8496999.stm | work=BBC News | title=Swindon 4–1 Stockport | date=23 February 2010}}</ref>
After making a brief appearance for Pompey on 4 October, Ritchie was loaned again to Swindon Town, on a one-month deal.<ref>[http://www.portsmouthfc.co.uk/LatestNews/news/Ritchie-Loaned-To-Swindon-1459.aspx Ritchie loaned to Swindon] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101007070023/http://www.portsmouthfc.co.uk/LatestNews/news/Ritchie-Loaned-To-Swindon-1459.aspx |date=7 October 2010 }}</ref> Two weeks later the deal was extended to two months.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/9101408.stm|title=BBC Sport – Football – Swindon extend loan of Portsmouth winger Matt Ritchie|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
On 7 January 2011, Swindon Town signed Ritchie on a two-and-a-half year deal for an undisclosed fee.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} He added to his tally with goals against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] in a 3–2 loss, a 4–1 loss to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], a 1–1 draw with [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] and a 2–1 loss against Notts County. Despite Swindon Town being relegated to League Two, Ritchie was named the Robins' Player of the Season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Matt Ritchie wins Swindon Town's player of the year|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/swindon_town/9474972.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 May 2011|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
Under manager [[Paolo Di Canio]] in League Two, he retained his first team place in the starting eleven and scoring form with ten goals that season. During the season, Ritchie was linked with League One clubs, with the likes of Bournemouth interested in signing the player.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bournemouth fail in bid for Swindon Town's Matt Ritchie|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15870897|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 November 2011|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> After Bournemouth's bid for him was rejected, manager Di Canio said that he was worth about £2 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Di Canio puts £2m price tag on Swindon Town's Ritchie|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15895163|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> In March, he won the Football League Two Player of the Year for 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ritchie scoops League Two honour|url=http://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/pompey/ritchie-scoops-league-two-honour-1-3616685|publisher=Portsmouth News|date=13 March 2012|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> With teammate [[Paul Caddis]] he was named in the PFA League Two Team of the Year.<ref name=PFATOTY1112>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/17797832 |title=Arsenal striker Robin van Persie named PFA Player of the Year |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 April 2012 |accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref>
Ahead of a new season in League One, Swindon turned down a £900,000 offer from a League One club for Ritchie, insisting he would be sold for £2.5 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Swindon Town turn down new bid for Matt Ritchie|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18883762|publisher=BBC Sport|date=18 July 2012|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> Shortly afterwards he signed a new contract, keeping him at the club until 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Matt Ritchie signs Swindon Town contract extension|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19523943|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 September 2012|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
===AFC Bournemouth=== On 30 January 2013, Ritchie signed for AFC Bournemouth on a three-and-a-half year deal for £400,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/21265257|title=Matt Ritchie: Bournemouth sign Swindon Town winger|date=30 January 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref><ref>[http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12691/8457035/League-One-Bournemouth-have-signed-winger-Matt-Ritchie-from-Swindon "League One: Bournemouth have signed winger Matt Ritchie from Swindon"] Sky Sports. 30 January 2013. Retrieved 30 January 2013.</ref> After leaving Swindon Town, he said that he was surprised to leave the club and that he had left with a "heavy heart".<ref>{{cite news|title=Matt Ritchie: Swindon exit saddens Bournemouth winger|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21286981|publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref> However, Di Canio claimed that the club sold Ritchie behind his back.<ref>{{cite news|title=Paolo Di Canio: Swindon Town manager 'considers future'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21300099|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 February 2013|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
He made his debut on 2 February in a 3–0 win over [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]]. Ritchie scored his first goal for his new team on 23 March in a 4–1 win over [[Bury F.C.|Bury]]. That win was the first of an eight match run of successive wins, including a brace for Ritchie in a 3–1 victory over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]], that culminated in clinching promotion to the Championship.<ref name="sb1213" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Mitchener|first1=Mark|title=Bournemouth 3 – 1 Carlisle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22133176|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 April 2015|date=20 April 2013}}</ref>
He was a key performer for Bournemouth during the 2014–15 season. His form helped the side to top the Championship and won him international recognition with [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]. By April, he had scored 11 goals and provided 13 assists for his team. Ritchie's form saw him voted the [[Football League]]'s best player in a poll by ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cusick|first1=Aiden|title=Bournemouth's Matt Ritchie Tops Four Four Two's Football League Top 50 Poll|url=http://www.90min.com/posts/2017319-bournemouth-s-matt-ritchie-tops-fourfourtwo-s-football-league-top-50-poll|publisher=90 Minutes|accessdate=3 April 2015|date=1 April 2015}}</ref>
On 19 September 2015, he scored his first ever goal in the [[Premier League]], coming on for Bournemouth in a 2–0 home win against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bournemouth 2–0 Sunderland|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34191881|website = BBC Sport|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref> On 25 October 2015, Ritchie scored his team's only goal of the game after just 1 minute, in Bournemouth's 5–1 drubbing by [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham.]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Bournemouth 1–5 Tottenham Hotspur|url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34564964|website = BBC Sport|accessdate = 2015-10-26}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== {{Quote box|width=20%|align=right|quote="I'm the penalty taker! [[Aleksandar Mitrović (footballer)|Mitro]] is a striker, everyone wants to score as many goals as possible. I've been on penalties since [[Dwight Gayle|Dwight]] missed one early doors. I wasn’t going to give it up."|source= <small>Ritchie, speaking to [[Talksport]], on the penalty incident against Preston.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/matt-ritchie-talks-mitrovic-penalty-12081631|title=Matt Ritchie talks the Mitrovic penalty incident and whether Newcastle can win the EFL Cup|work=Newcastle Chronicle|first=Lee|last=Ryder|date=25 October 2016|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref></small>}} On 1 July 2016, Ritchie signed a five-year contract with newly relegated [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], becoming the third signing under manager [[Rafael Benítez]].<ref name="Ritchie Signs On At St. James' Park">{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20160701/ritchie-signs-on-at-st-james-park_2281670_5696102 | title=Ritchie Signs On At St. James' Park | publisher=Newcastle United | date=1 July 2016 | accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> He made his debut for the club in a 1–0 loss to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], playing the full 90 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36921094|title=Fulham 1–0 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 August 2016|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> His first goal, a penalty, came two matches later in a 4–1 win over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37030439|title=Newcastle United 4–1 Reading|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 August 2016|accessdate=5 September 2017}}</ref> From then on, Ritchie would become the club's designated penalty taker and had a 100% success rate in all competitions, converting from the spot five times. He was involved in two penalty related incidents over the course of the season. On 25 October, he refused to hand the ball to [[Aleksandar Mitrović (footballer)|Aleksandar Mitrović]], tucking it under his shirt, before scoring the third goal in a 6–0 win over [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37686639|title=Newcastle United 6–0 Preston North End|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 October 2016|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> On 5 April 2017, against [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]], Ritchie scored a penalty, but it was not awarded due to encroachment by [[Dwight Gayle]]. However, referee [[Keith Stroud]] awarded a direct free kick to Burton, rather than allowing Ritchie to retake the penalty. Ultimately, it did not matter as he scored the winner anyway, to keep Newcastle in the promotion hunt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39426682|title=Newcastle 1–0 Burton Albion|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 April 2017|accessdate=15 April 2017}}</ref> Ritchie's season was ended by suspension, when he argued with a match official after a home draw with [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39735735|title=Matt Ritchie: Newcastle United winger misses rest of season through suspension|publisher=BBC Sport|date=27 April 2017|accessdate=8 July 2017}}</ref> Ritchie scored sixteen goals in all competitions, with only Gayle having netted more than the Scotsman.
On 26 August, Ritchie assisted [[Ciaran Clark]] for the second goal of the match, as Newcastle got their first win of the season, beating [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] 3–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40984016|title=Newcastle United 3–0 West Ham United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 August 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> He was then credited with the assists for the goals scored by [[Jamaal Lascelles]] and [[Christian Atsu]] in wins over [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] and [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41139095|title=Swansea City 0–1 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 September 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41210052|title=Newcastle United 2–1 Stoke City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 September 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> On 28 November, he assisted both Newcastle goals from set-pieces in a 2–2 draw with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41210052|title=West Bromwich Albion 2–2 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 November 2017|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> In the second half of the season, Ritchie scored three times, all in home wins over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42934988|title=Newcastle United 1–0 Manchester United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 February 2018|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43267239|title=Newcastle United 3–0 Southampton|publisher=BBC Sport|date=10 March 2018|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43686474|title=Newcastle United 2–1 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 April 2018|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref>
On 11 August 2018, Ritchie set up [[Joselu]] for the equaliser, in a 2–1 home loss to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45067372|title=Newcastle United 1–2 Tottenham Hotspur|publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> He was taken off in the second half, much to his disapproval; his emotional outburst on the bench was captured on television cameras, and was discussed on the following night's "2 Good 2 Bad" segment on ''[[Match of the Day 2]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/08/11/matt-ritchie-goes-ballistic-newcastle-bench-subbed-off-tottenham-7827421|title=Matt Ritchie goes ballistic on Newcastle bench after being subbed off against Tottenham|work=Metro|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=23 August 2018}}</ref> On 26 November, Ritchie assisted Clark for the second goal of the match in a 2–1 away win over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], although in the second half, he missed a sitter from two yards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46256914|title=Burnley 1–2 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 November 2018|accessdate=1 December 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Under [[FIFA eligibility rules]], Ritchie was eligible for the national teams of England, where he was born and raised, and Scotland, his father's native land.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/31909618|title=Matt Ritchie: Bournemouth winger's joy at Scotland call-up|date=16 March 2015|work=BBC}}</ref> On 16 March 2015, he was called up to the [[Scotland national football team]] for a friendly against [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016]] [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualification|qualifier]] against [[Gibraltar national football team|Gibraltar]]. Ritchie made his debut against Northern Ireland on 25 March at [[Hampden Park]], and took the 85th-minute corner which set up [[Christophe Berra]]'s header for the only goal of the game.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scotland 1–0 Northern Ireland|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/31917339|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 March 2015|accessdate=25 March 2015}}</ref> On 5 June he scored his first international goal, a 20-yard strike which was the only goal of a friendly victory over [[Qatar national football team|Qatar]] at [[Easter Road]] in [[Edinburgh]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lamont|first1=Alasdair|title=Scotland 1–0 Qatar|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32926060|accessdate=5 June 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=5 June 2015}}</ref> His second goal came in a European Championship qualifier against [[Poland national football team|Poland]] at Hampden Park on 8 October 2015, for which he won "Goal of the Year" award from the [[Scottish Football Association|Scottish FA]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/14133215.Matt_Ritchie_wins_Scotland_Goal_of_the_Year/?ref=rss |title=AFC Bournemouth's Matt Ritchie wins Scotland Goal of the Year from Scottish FA |work=Daily Echo |publisher= |date=9 December 2015 |accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>

{{use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Martin Dúbravka | image = Martin Dubravka 2018.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Dúbravka in 2018 | fullname = Martin Dúbravka<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=15 February 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1989|1|15|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Žilina]], Czechoslovakia | height = 1.90 m | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubnumber = 12 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[MŠK Žilina|Žilina]] | years1 = 2008–2013 | clubs1 = [[MŠK Žilina|Žilina]] | caps1 = 98 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014–2016 | clubs2 = [[Esbjerg fB|Esbjerg]] | caps2 = 66 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2016–2017 | clubs3 = [[FC Slovan Liberec|Slovan Liberec]] | caps3 = 28 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2017–2018 | clubs4 = [[AC Sparta Prague|Sparta Prague]] | caps4 = 11 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2018 | clubs5 = → [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] (loan) | caps5 = 12 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2018– | clubs6 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps6 = 31 | goals6 = 0 |nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 |nationalteam1 = [[Slovakia national under-19 football team|Slovakia U19]] |nationalcaps1 = 6 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2009–2010 |nationalteam2 = [[Slovakia national under-21 football team|Slovakia U21]] |nationalcaps2 = 12 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |nationalyears3 = 2014– |nationalteam3 = [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] |nationalcaps3 = 17 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | club-update = 17:14, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 21 March 2019 }}
'''Martin Dúbravka''' ({{IPA-sk|ˈmaɾtin ˈduːbɾaʊ̯ka}}; born 15 February 1989) is a Slovakian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and the [[Slovakia national football team]].
==Early life== As a child, Dúbravka enjoyed playing ice hockey as well as football, and could have moved into the former sport were it not for a leg injury he sustained when he was five years old.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/04/13/martin-dubravka-interview-hyperactive-ice-hockey-goalkeeper |title= Exclusive Martin Dubravka interview: From hyperactive ice-hockey goalkeeper to Newcastle cult hero – via a freak machete injury |work= Daily Telegraph |first=Luke |last=Edwards |date= 13 April 2018 |accessdate= 13 April 2018}}</ref>
==Club career== Dúbravka made his senior team debut in a 5–2 home win against [[MFK Dubnica|Dubnica]] on 26 May 2009. In the [[2009–10 Slovak Superliga|next season]] he played 26 [[Slovak Superliga|Corgoň Liga]] games, finishing as a league champion. He became a first choice after the transfer of [[Dušan Perniš]] in January 2010. He qualified with Žilina to the [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League]] and played all 6 group games. He kept a [[Shutout#Association football|clean sheet]] in the [[2010–11 UEFA Champions League qualifying phase and play-off round#Play-off round|play-off round]] against [[AC Sparta Prague|Sparta Prague]].<ref name=joinsparta>{{cite web|url=https://fotbal.idnes.cz/liberecky-brankar-martin-dubravka-prestoupil-do-sparty-pjw-/fotbal.aspx?c=A170612_162313_fotbal_min|title=Další nováček ve Spartě, z Liberce přichází brankář Dúbravka|language=cs|work=idnes.cz|date=12 June 2017|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref> On 30 January 2014, he signed a 3½ year deal with the [[Danish Superliga]] club [[Esbjerg fB]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=2048808.html|title=Esbjerg bring in Dúbravka from Žilina|first=|last=uefa.com|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref>
Dúbravka joined [[FC Slovan Liberec|Slovan Liberec]] of the [[Czech First League]] in July 2016 on a one-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fotbal.idnes.cz/fotbal-liberec-dubravka-0s0-/fot_pohary.aspx?c=A160728_2262637_fot_pohary_tof|title=Liberec ulovil brankáře Dúbravku. Zachytá si už proti vídeňské Admiře?|language=cs|work=idnes.cz|date=28 July 2016|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref><ref name=joinsparta/> He joined Sparta Prague in June 2017, signing a three-year contract.<ref name=joinsparta/>
===Newcastle United=== In January 2018, [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] showed interest in Dúbravka, initially offering Sparta Prague a [[loan (sports)|loan]] for €500,000, with an option to sign in the summer for €4.5 million. He finally joined the [[Premier League]] side on 31 January 2018, the final day of the [[List of English football transfers winter 2017–18|winter transfer window]] on a half-year loan deal, due to expire at the end of [[2017–18 Newcastle United F.C. season|2017–18 season]]. According to isport.cz, he joined the club for €2 million, with an option to sign in the summer for €4 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sport.aktuality.sk/c/318531/newcastle-a-sparta-sa-dohodli-dubravka-mieri-do-premier-league/|title=Newcastle a Sparta sa dohodli, Dúbravka mieri do Premier League!|language=sk|author=SPORT.SK, s.r.o. & Ringier Axel Springer Slovakia a.s.|publisher=|date=31 January 2018|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref>
He made his debut on 11 February, playing a pivotal role and keeping a clean sheet in a 1–0 win against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. He became the sixteenth Slovak player and only the second Slovak goalkeeper, after [[Ján Mucha]], to start in a Premier League fixture. After a very successful loan spell, he signed permanently for Newcastle on 30 May for an undisclosed fee of around 5 million euros.<ref>https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/latest-news/magpies-confirm-permanent-d%C3%BAbravka-deal{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On 17 February 2019 in [[Durham, England|Durham]], Dúbravka was recognised as the Player of the Year 2018 by [[Football Writers' Association|North East Football Writers' Association]], joing the alikes of [[Alan Shearer]], [[Kevin Keegan]] or [[Shay Given]]. He became the 7th goalkeeper to win the award, in its 39 seasons. Dúbravka stated that he was happy to win the award because "amazing players have won this trophy before". <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/latest-news/dubravka-receives-north-east-football-writers-association-player-of-the-year-award|title=Dúbravka receives North East Football Writers' Association player of the year award|website=Newcastle United Football Club|language=en|access-date=2019-02-18}}</ref>
==International career== Dúbravka, a former [[Slovakia national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Slovakia national under-21 football team|under-21]] national player, was selected for the [[Slovakia national football team]] for the [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying]] home game against [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]].
Dúbravka made his national team debut against [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]] on 23 May 2014 (2–0 win).<ref name=debrep>[http://sport.sme.sk/c/7213206/slovensko-vyhralo-nad-ciernou-horou-20-kozakovi-chybala-atmosfera.html Slovensko vyhralo nad Čiernou Horou 2:0, Kozákovi chýbala atmosféra], SME.sk, retrieved 25. 5. 2014 {{sk icon}}</ref>
In January 2017, he played his first full game for the national team, having played 45 minutes in both of his previous matches. While he was benched against [[Uganda national football team|Uganda]] (1–3 loss), on 12 January he was fielded in an unofficial friendly match against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates|UAE]]. Slovakia lost the game 0–6, despite only trailing 0–1 at half time. This match also marked the first time Dúbravka conceded in the national team and he was also Slovak [[captain (association football)|captain]] for the game, being the most experienced with international football.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportinak.sk/online-prenos-pripravny-zapas-futbal--slovensko---uganda|title=Prípravný futbalový zápas: Slovensko prehralo s Ugandou 1:3|language=sk|website=www.sportinak.sk|date=8 January 2017|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportinak.sk/online-prenos-pripravny-zapas-futbal--slovensko---svedsko-teraz|title=Slováci prehrali so Švédskom 0:6. To je niečo strašné, hovorí Kozák|language=sk|website=www.sportinak.sk|date=12 January 2017|accessdate=4 February 2018}}</ref>
He made his competitive debut in a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group F|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier]], against [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]] (2–1 win), on 10 June 2017, when the preferred goalkeeper in the qualification, [[Matúš Kozáčik]], was unavailable due to injury. He however achieved his first competitive clean sheet on 1 September in a home [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group F|qualifier]] against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]]. Slovakia won thanks to an 81st-minute goal by [[Adam Nemec]]. Just as in the previous [[cap (sport)|cap]], Dúbravka was chosen due to a prolonged injury of Kozáčik. After Kozáčik's return to the squad, Dúbravka remained preferred for the remaining matches against [[England national football team|England]], [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] and [[Malta national football team|Malta]]. In the match against Scotland, Dúbravka made a series of saves before he was finally beaten by an [[own goal]] from [[Martin Škrtel]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/scotland/41525121 |title=Scotland still in it after dramatic late win over Slovakia |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Tom |last=English |date=6 October 2017 |accessdate=1 February 2018}}</ref>
===Ján Kozák's resignation incident=== Dúbravka was nominated for a double fixture against [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] and [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] on 13 October and 16 October 2018, respectively.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportdnes.sk/futbal/trener-kozak-nominoval-na-cesko-a-svedsko-aj-skrtela-ci-pekarika-pozvanku-dostali-a-mladici-zo/|title=Tréner Kozák nominoval na Česko a Švédsko aj Škrtela či Pekaríka, pozvánku dostali a mladíci zo Serie A|work=SportDnes.sk|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> He played the entirety of both games, but was also involved in an incident, that had led to resignation of [[Ján Kozák (footballer, born 1954)|Ján Kozák]], then Slovakia's longest-serving and most successful coach, who introduced him to the national team.
Dúbravka violated the code of conduct of national team players, along with [[Michal Šulla]], [[Norbert Gyömbér]], [[Ľubomír Šatka]], [[Milan Škriniar]], [[Vladimír Weiss (footballer, born 1989)|Vladimír Weiss]] and [[Stanislav Lobotka]]. On the night of 13 October 2018, after loss in Slovakia's second [[2018–19 UEFA Nations League|UEFA Nations League]] fixture and a derby match against Czech Republic (1–2), they left the hotel and went out, missed the bedtime and violated the wellness policy, regarding regeneration and rehabilitation. They were allegedly discovered by Ján Kozák at about midnight, admitting to the incident and apologising during the next day. Ján Kozák resigned from the national team during the afternoon of 14 October, revealing the details of his decision in a press conference on 18 October, to avoid distractions during the preparation for the fixture against Sweden, that was managed by his former assistant [[Štefan Tarkovič]] on a caretaker basis. Kozák cited his inability to work with such squad under these conditions as the primary reason, as almost a third of the team was concerned, including players, those Kozák described as crucial, with Dúbravka being a part of this group. President of [[Slovak Football Association|SFZ]], Ján Kováčik, said that the players will be punished by not receiving any financial rewards for future nominations and performances in the national team during the upcoming qualification cycle. During the press conference, Kozák also revealed that Dúbravka had claimed "difficult times at Newcastle" as one of the reasons for his conduct.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://sport.sme.sk/c/20940265/online-jan-kozak-o-rezignacii-tlacova-konferencia.html|title=Kozák vymenoval hráčov, ktorí po zápase s Českom porušili večierku (minúta po minúte)|last=a.s.|first=Petit Press|work=sport.sme.sk|access-date=2018-10-18|language=sk}}</ref>
On 19 October, SFZ published Dúbravka's official statement. He acknowledged that missing the bedtime was a violation, but maintained that the rest was within norms. He accepted any sanctions and stressed that the conduct was not aimed against Kozák, commenting that he regrets that Kozák didn't accept an apology from the trespassers. He also stated that Kozák's resignation surprised him, because of the good relations within the team.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.futbalsfz.sk/sr-a-hraci|title=SR A – Všetci siedmi reprezentanti sa ospravedlňujú: Mrzí nás to, bola to chyba a budeme za ňu niesť následky|last=zväz|first=Slovenský futbalový|website=www.futbalsfz.sk|language=sk|access-date=2018-10-21}}</ref>
==Style of play== Dúbravka is a third-generation [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]: his father and grandfather also played in the position.<ref name = "reluctant">{{cite news|title=Reluctant keeper Martin Dubravka makes right impression at Newcastle|first=Louise|last=Taylor|date=23 February 2018|accessdate=24 February 2018|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/23/martin-dubravka-goalkeeper-newcastle-bournemouth}}</ref> Dúbravka has been dubbed the "quintessential sweeper-keeper" due to his "outstanding footwork" and he believes "in modern football the keeper's almost like a [[libero (football)|libero]]. You need to play with the ball, not just kick it long".<ref name="reluctant" />
Louise Taylor of ''[[The Guardian]]'' christened Dúbravka the "reluctant keeper" after he admitted his favourite position to play is [[right winger (association football)|right wing]]; he sometimes plays as an outfielder in training and coaching staff have suggested that he switch to a [[midfielder|midfield]] role.<ref name="reluctant" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Yoshinori Muto | image = Yoshinori-Muto-2015-07.jpg | image_size = | caption = Muto with [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz]] in 2015 | fullname = Yoshinori Muto<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127 |title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=3 September 2018 |accessdate=4 September 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1992|7|15}} | birth_place = [[Setagaya, Tokyo]], Japan | height = 1.79 m<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tournament.fifadata.com/documents/FWC/2018/pdf/FWC_2018_SQUADLISTS.PDF |title=2018 FIFA World Cup: List of players |publisher=FIFA |format=PDF |page=15 |date=14 July 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubnumber = 13 | youthyears1 = 2008–2010 | youthclubs1 = [[FC Tokyo]] | youthyears2 = 2010–2013 | youthclubs2 = [[Keio University]] | years1 = 2013–2015 | clubs1 = [[FC Tokyo]] | caps1 = 51 | goals1 = 23 | years2 = 2015–2018 | clubs2 = [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]] | caps2 = 66 | goals2 = 20 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps3 = 13 | goals3 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2014– | nationalteam1 = [[Japan national football team|Japan]] | nationalcaps1 = 29 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | club-update = 17:32, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:41, 1 February 2019 (UTC) | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{fb|JPN}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[AFC Asian Cup]]}} {{Medal|RU|[[2019 AFC Asian Cup|2019 UAE]]|[[Japan national football team|Team]]}} }} {{Nihongo|'''Yoshinori Muto'''|武藤 嘉紀|Mutō Yoshinori|born 15 July 1992}} is a Japanese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for English club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and the [[Japan national football team|Japan national team]] as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]].
He started his career with [[J1 League]] club [[FC Tokyo]] in 2013 who he played with for three seasons. In May 2015, he signed for German club [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]] where he amassed 72 appearances and scored 23 goals before moving to [[Premier League]] club Newcastle United in August 2018.
==Club career== ===FC Tokyo=== As a child, Muto joined FC Tokyo's youth system, where he kept developing until 2010. He then enrolled in the Faculty of Economics of [[Keio University]] but kept playing football, for Keio's team. Despite an injury which sidelined him, in his first season with Keio he won the "Rookie of the Year" title.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://keispo.org/wordpress/?p=5171 |title=【ソッカー男子】開幕前取材、第3弾 武藤嘉紀編 |publisher=Keio Sports Press |date=3 May 2011 |language=japanese}}</ref>
In 2012 and 2013, FC Tokyo included him in their roster as a "Special Designated Player",<ref>{{cite news |title=武藤嘉紀選手（慶應義塾大学）「ＪＦＡ・Ｊリーグ特別指定選手」承認のお知らせ |url=http://www.fctokyo.co.jp/?p=148757 |language=japanese |publisher=FC Tokyo |date=26 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302075513/http://www.fctokyo.co.jp/?p=148757 |archivedate=2 March 2014}}</ref> an option that allows J-League clubs to field university players without a professional contract. However, he got on the pitch just once, at the end of a match in July 2013.
In 2014, he signed his first professional contract with FC Tokyo<ref>{{cite web |title=武藤嘉紀選手(慶應義塾大学)来季新加入内定のお知らせ |url=http://www.fctokyo.co.jp/?p=180838 |language=japanese |date=12 December 2013 |publisher=FC Tokyo |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131222115444/http://www.fctokyo.co.jp/?p=180838 |archivedate=22 December 2013}}</ref> and was given the shirt number 14. Coach Massimo Ficcadenti decided to use him from the first league round and, at the end of the season, Muto reached 33 appearances and scored 13 goals, matching the top debut record in the Japanese first division.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea scout out Muto |url=http://www.marca.com/en/2015/04/09/en/football/international_football/1428615427.html |newspaper=Marca |date=9 April 2015}}</ref> At the end of the season, he was part of the J-League's Best XI.<ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Orlowitz |title=Yasuhito Endo awarded 2014 J-League MVP; FC Tokyo and Gamba Osaka spearhead Best XI |url=http://footballchannel.asia/2014/12/09/post1086/ |publisher=Football Channel Asia}}</ref>
Muto graduated from Keio University in March 2015, and the following month was subject to a bid by [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Yoshinori Muto: Chelsea make bid for Japanese striker |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32230300 |accessdate=9 April 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 April 2015}}</ref> In April, he was elected as March's MVP (Player of the Month) in the J-League.<ref>{{cite news |title=Muto named Coca-Cola MVP winners in March |url=http://www.jleague.jp/en/news/20150411-03.html |accessdate=11 April 2015 |work=JLeague Sport |date=11 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419024121/http://www.jleague.jp/en/news/20150411-03.html |archivedate=19 April 2015}}</ref>
===Mainz 05=== On 30 May 2015, Muto joined [[Bundesliga]] club [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]] on a four-year contract until 2019.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mainz 05 sign Yoshinori Muto |url=http://www.mainz05.de/mainz05/en/aktuell/news/news-detail/article/mainz-05-verpflichtet-yoshinori-muto.html |accessdate=30 May 2015 |publisher=Mainz 05 |date=30 May 2015}}</ref> On 31 October 2015, he scored a [[hat-trick]] for the first time in his career and also became the second Japanese player after [[Naohiro Takahara]] to score a hat-trick in the Bundesliga, in his team's 3–3 draw against [[FC Augsburg]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/sports/2015/11/01/soccer/muto-hits-hat-trick-mainz-draw/#.VjhdKNLhBRB |title=Muto hits hat-trick in Mainz draw |newspaper=The Japan Times |date=1 November 2015 |accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== [[Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] announced on 27 July 2018 that they had reached a deal to sign Muto, pending him being granted a [[Work permit (United Kingdom)|UK work permit]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/newcastle-united-confirm-sealed-transfer-14962597.amp |title=Newcastle United confirm they have all but sealed the transfer of Yoshinori Muto |newspaper=Evening Chronicle |first=Lee |last=Ryder |date=27 July 2018 |accessdate=27 July 2018}}</ref> He was granted the work permit on 2 August, officially becoming a Newcastle player on a four-year contract as part of a £9.5 million fee.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/11457570/yoshinori-muto-completes-newcastle-move-after-work-permit-granted |title=Yoshinori Muto signs for Newcastle after work permit granted |publisher=Sky Sports |first=James |last=Dale |date=2 August 2018 |accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref>
Muto’s first goal for Newcastle came in a 3–2 away loss to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at [[Old Trafford]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/oct/06/manchester-united-v-newcastle-united-premier-league-live}}</ref>
==International career== Muto made his debut for [[Japan national football team|Japan]] on 5 September 2014 in a 2–0 friendly defeat to [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] at the [[Sapporo Dome]], replacing [[Yusuke Minagawa]] after 58 minutes.<ref>{{cite web |title=Japan 0–2 Uruguay: Cavani on target for Celeste |url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/japan-vs-uruguay/1837187/report |accessdate=9 April 2015 |publisher=Goal.com |date=5 September 2014}}</ref> Four days later at [[Yokohama]]'s [[Nissan Stadium (Yokohama)|Nissan Stadium]] he scored his first international goal, coming on as a half-time substitute against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] and scoring the first goal of a 2–2 draw six minutes later.<ref>{{cite web |last=West |first=Harry |title=Japan 2–2 Venezuela: Kawashima mistake costs Aguirre maiden win |url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/japan-vs-venezuela/1837189/report |accessdate=10 April 2015 |publisher=Goal.com |date=9 September 2014}}</ref>
As a substitute, Muto played all of Japan's matches at the [[2015 AFC Asian Cup]] in Australia, ending with defeat to the [[United Arab Emirates national football team|United Arab Emirates]] in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news |title=Asian Cup 2015: UAE complete shock win over Japan to reach semi-final after penalty shootout dramatics |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-01-23/uae-japan-asian-cup/6043964 |accessdate=9 April 2015 |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=23 January 2015}}</ref>
On 31 May 2018, he was named in Japan's final 23-man squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-worldcup-jpn-squad/football-nishino-opts-for-experienced-japan-squad-for-world-cup-idUKKCN1IW101 |title=Football – Nishino opts for experienced Japan squad for World Cup |work=Reuters |language=English |date=31 May 2018 |accessdate=3 August 2018}}</ref>

nationalteam-update = }} '''Ayoze Pérez Gutiérrez''' ({{IPA-es|aˈʝoθe ˈpeɾeθ}}; born 29 July 1993) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] and [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].
He began his career at hometown club [[CD Tenerife]], where he received several personal awards for his performances in the [[2013–14 Segunda División]] season before joining Newcastle for around €3 million.
Ayoze has represented Spain internationally at [[Spain national under-21 football team|under-21 level]].
==Club career==
===Tenerife=== Born in [[Santa Cruz de Tenerife]], [[Canary Islands]], Ayoze finished his formation with local [[CD Tenerife|Tenerife]], making his senior debuts with the [[CD Tenerife B|B-team]] in the 2011–12 season, in the [[Tercera División|fourth division]].<ref name=GoalMachine>{{cite news|url=http://www.laopinion.es/deportes/2012/06/07/maquina-goles/417237.html|title=Una máquina de hacer goles|trans-title=A goal machine|newspaper=[[La Opinión de Tenerife]]|language=Spanish|date=7 June 2012|accessdate=23 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://botaheliodoro.com/entrevista-a-ayoze/ |title=Entrevista a Ayoze |trans-title=Interview to Ayoze |publisher=Bota Heliodoro |language=Spanish |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=16 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726200532/http://botaheliodoro.com/entrevista-a-ayoze/ |archivedate=26 July 2014 |df= }}</ref> He appeared with the main squad in the [[Segunda División B|third level]] in the [[2012–13 Segunda División B|following campaign]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://clubdeportivotenerife.es/pagina.asp?idp=11214&ids=6 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140924154604/http://clubdeportivotenerife.es/pagina.asp?idp=11214&ids=6 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 September 2014 |title=Ocho jugadores del CD Tenerife B realizarán la pretemporada con el primer equipo |trans-title=Eight CD Tenerife B players will make the pre-season with the first team |publisher=Tenerife's official website |language=Spanish |date=14 July 2012 |accessdate=24 September 2014 }}</ref> featuring in 16 matches and scoring once as the ''Blanquiazules'' [[2012–13 Segunda División B|returned]] to [[Segunda División|division two]] after a two-year absence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://clubdeportivotenerife.es/pagina.asp?idp=11912&ids=6 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140924154555/http://clubdeportivotenerife.es/pagina.asp?idp=11912&ids=6 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 September 2014 |title=Ayoze Pérez, otro canterano que vuelve a poner en valor la formación en el CD Tenerife |trans-title=Ayoze Pérez, another ''canterano'' who enhances CD Tenerife's formation |publisher=Tenerife's official website |language=Spanish |date=22 December 2012 |accessdate=24 September 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://clubdeportivotenerife.es/pagina.asp?idp=12478&ids=6 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140924154613/http://clubdeportivotenerife.es/pagina.asp?idp=12478&ids=6 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 September 2014 |title=Catorce goleadores del CD Tenerife en lo que va de temporada |trans-title=Fourteen goalscorers of CD Tenerife in the season |publisher=Tenerife's official website |language=Spanish |date=6 May 2013 |accessdate=24 September 2014 }}</ref>
After impressing in the 2013 pre-season,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2013/08/12/futbol/equipos/tenerife/1376300611.html|title=Ayoze pide paso para ser titular|trans-title=Ayoze calls on starting XI duties|work=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|language=Spanish|date=12 August 2013|accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref> Ayoze played his first professional match on 18 August, starting in a 1–0 away defeat against [[AD Alcorcón|Alcorcón]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2013/08/18/futbol/2adivision/1376853520.html|title=El Alcorcón sigue abonado a los finales con suspense|trans-title=Alcorcón and close games a marriage made in heaven|work=Marca|location=Spain|language=Spanish|date=18 August 2013|accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal in the "silver category" on 29 September, in a 1–0 home win over [[Real Madrid Castilla]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2013/09/29/futbol/equipos/tenerife/1380480393.html|title=El Tenerife respira y el Castilla se ahoga|trans-title=Tenerife breathes and Castilla drowns|work=Marca|location=Spain|language=Spanish|date=29 September 2013|accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref>
On 23 March of the following year Ayoze scored his first [[hat-trick]] of his career, starting in a 5–0 thrashing against [[SD Ponferradina|Ponferradina]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2014/03/23/futbol/2adivision/1395601897.html|title='Manita' tinerfeña con sabor a 'playoff' a costa de los bercianos|trans-title=Tenerife's ''manita'' with a taste of 'playoff' at the Bercians' expense|work=Marca|location=Spain|language=Spanish|date=23 March 2014|accessdate=24 March 2014}}</ref> This was one of the performances which earned him the league's Player of the Month award,<ref name=lfp>{{cite news|title=Premios BBVA a los mejores de marzo|trans-title=BBVA awards for the best in March|url=http://www.lfp.es/noticias/premios-bbva-a-los-mejores-de-marzo|accessdate=8 November 2014|publisher=[[Liga de Fútbol Profesional]]|date=7 April 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref> which he retained for a second consecutive time while his manager [[Álvaro Cervera]] won [[Segunda División Manager of the Month|the equivalent]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Premios BBVA a los mejores de abril|trans-title=BBVA Awards for the best in April|url=http://www.laliga.es/noticias/premios-bbva-a-los-mejores-de-abril|accessdate=15 March 2016|publisher=Liga de Fútbol Profesional|date=30 April 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref>
In October 2014, Ayoze won the ''Breakthrough Player in the 2013–14 Segunda División'' and ''Best Attacking Midfielder in the 2013–14 Segunda División'' awards at the [[Liga de Fútbol Profesional|LFP]] Awards Ceremony.<ref name=bp1314>{{cite news|title=Ayoze, winner of the '2013–14 Liga Adelante Breakthrough Player'award|url=http://www.lfp.es/en/news/ayoze-winner-of-the-2013-14-liga-adelante-breakthrough-playeraward|accessdate=28 October 2014|publisher=LFP|date=27 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=bam1314>{{cite news|title=Ayoze Pérez, 'Best Attacking Midfielder in the 2013–14 Liga Adelante'|url=http://www.lfp.es/en/news/ayoze-perez-best-attacking-midfielder-in-the-2013-14-liga-adelante|accessdate=28 October 2014|publisher=LFP|date=27 October 2014}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== On 5 June 2014 Ayoze rejected interest from [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] and [[F.C. Porto|Porto]] to join [[Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] for an estimated €3 million fee.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/sport/football/newcastle-united/ayoze-perez-snubbed-barcelona-and-real-madrid-to-sign-for-newcastle-1-6918975 | title=Ayoze Pérez snubbed Barcelona AND Real Madrid to sign for Newcastle | work=[[Shields Gazette]] | date=27 October 2014 | accessdate=27 October 2014 | first1=Miles | last1=Starforth}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Internacional/inglaterra/interior.aspx?content_id=887095 | title=Newcastle contrata Ayoze Pérez | trans-title=Newcastle signs Ayoze Pérez | work=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]] | date=5 June 2014 | accessdate=6 June 2014 | language=Portuguese | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606223356/http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Internacional/inglaterra/interior.aspx?content_id=887095 | archivedate=6 June 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.marca.com/2014/05/21/futbol/equipos/tenerife/1400685788.html | title=Ayoze Pérez, al Newcastle |trans-title=Ayoze Pérez, to Newcastle | work=Marca|location=Spain | date=21 May 2014 | accessdate=6 June 2014 | language=Spanish}}</ref> The deal was confirmed a day later.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140606/magpies-confirm-ayoze-arrival_2281670_3886001 | title=Magpies Confirm Ayoze Arrival | publisher=Newcastle United | date=6 June 2014 | accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref> He made his league debut on 17 August, replacing fellow debutant [[Emmanuel Rivière]] in the 83rd minute of a 2–0 home defeat against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730044 | title=Newcastle 0–2 Man City | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | date=17 August 2014 | accessdate=17 August 2014 | first1=Saj | last1=Chowdhury}}</ref>
Ayoze scored his first goal in his first league start on 26 October, in a 2–1 away win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/313474/report | title=Premier League: Newcastle come from behind to beat Tottenham 2–1 at White Hart Lane | work=Sky Sports | date=26 October 2014 | accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> Six days later, as a half-time substitute for [[Papiss Cissé]], he scored the only goal of the game to defeat [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and give Newcastle their fourth successive win.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29768016 | title=Newcastle 1–0 Liverpool | publisher=BBC Sport | date=1 November 2014 | accessdate=1 November 2014 | first1=Saj | last1=Chowdhury}}</ref> On 9 November, Ayoze made it three league goals in as many games in a 2–0 away win against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite web | first1=Marc | last1=Higginson | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29868777 | title=West Bromwich Albion 0–2 Newcastle United | publisher=BBC Sport | date=9 November 2014 | accessdate=14 December 2014}}</ref> He scored less frequently in the second half of the season as Newcastle struggled, but his equaliser against the same opponents on 9 May 2015 ended a run of eight consecutive defeats under [[John Carver (footballer)|John Carver]], as Newcastle avoided relegation.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32561905 | title=Newcastle 1–1 West Brom | publisher=BBC Sport | date=9 May 2015 | accessdate=18 October 2015 | first1=Phil | last1=McNulty}}</ref>
Ayoze scored Newcastle's first in a 2–2 draw with title holders [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 26 September 2015.<ref>{{cite web | first1=Olsen | last1=Olsen | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34299598 | title=Newcastle 2–2 Chelsea | work=BBCSport | date=26 September 2015 | accessdate=26 September 2015}}</ref> On 18 October, he recorded a goal in a 6–2 rout of [[Norwich City]], Newcastle's first win of the [[2015–16 Premier League|season]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34498802 | title=Newcastle United 6–2 Norwich City | publisher=BBC Sport | date=18 October 2015 | accessdate=18 October 2015}}</ref> He scored the only goal of an away win at [[AFC Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on 7 November, with Newcastle's only shot on target.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34686457 | title=Bournemouth 0–1 Newcastle | publisher=BBC Sport | date=7 November 2015 | accessdate=7 November 2015 | first1=Alistair | last1=Magowan}}</ref> On 13 December, as a substitute, he scored an added-time winner at [[Tottenham Hotspur]], moving Newcastle out of the relegation places.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35018988 | title=Tottenham 1–2 Newcastle | publisher=BBC Sport | date=13 December 2015 | accessdate=13 December 2015 | first1=Neil | last1=Johnston}}</ref>
On 1 February 2016, Newcastle United announced that Ayoze signed a new contract, committing himself to the club until the summer of 2021.<ref name="Pérez Signs New Magpies Deal">{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20160201/perez-signs-new-magpies-deal_2281670_5311131 | title=Pérez Signs New Magpies Deal | publisher=Newcastle United | date=1 February 2016 | accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref>
Ayoze stayed with Newcastle despite a drop into the Championship, helping the club return to the Premiership immediately after one season. Ayoze ended the season with 9 goals in 25 appearances,<ref>https://www.whoscored.com/Players/135366/Show/Ayoze-P%C3%A9rez</ref> with 11 of them coming as starts, scoring key goals against title rivals Brighton<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39035302|title=Brighton & Hove Albion 1–2 Newcastle United|date=28 February 2017|publisher=BBC}}</ref> as well as Barnsley to help seal the Championship title on the final day of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39760419|title=Newcastle United 3–0 Barnsley|date=7 May 2017|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
He scored his first Premier League goal of the season in a 2–2 draw at [[Southampton F.C|Southampton]] on 15 October.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41541148|title=Southampton 2–2 Newcastle United}}</ref> He then scored in consecutive matches in a 1–0 away win over [[Stoke City F.C|Stoke City]]<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42411042|title=Stoke City 0–1 Newcastle United}}</ref> and a brace in a 3–1 home win over [[Luton Town F.C|Luton]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42519614|title=Newcastle United 3–1 Luton Town}}</ref> On 31 March 2018, Ayoze ended his 8-match goalless run by scoring the only goal in a victory over [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield]], in the 80th minute.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43524304|title=Newcastle United 1–0 Huddersfield Town}}</ref> Ayoze continued his good form with a goal and an assist each, in wins over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43602495|title=Leicester City 1–2 Newcastle}}</ref> and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43686474|title=Newcastle 2–1 Arsenal}}</ref>
==International career== On 29 August 2014, Ayoze received his first call-up to the [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain national under-21 team]] for the [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 4|2015 European Under-21 Championships qualifying]] matches against [[Hungary national under-21 football team|Hungary]] and [[Austria national under-21 football team|Austria]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=King|first1=Dan|title=Ayoze's Spanish Selection|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140829/ayozes-spanish-selection_2281670_4107385|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|accessdate=29 August 2014|date=29 August 2014}}</ref> He made his under-21 debut as a 77th-minute substitute for [[Munir El Haddadi]] against Hungary on 4 September.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Watson-Broughton|first1=Matthew|title=Ñíguez fires Spain to Hungary success|url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2015/matches/round=2000412/match=2011457/postmatch/report/index.html|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=4 September 2014|date=4 September 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Ayoze's older brother, Samuel, is also a forward, who has played for [[Blyth Spartans A.F.C.|Blyth Spartans]] and [[Berwick Rangers F.C.|Berwick Rangers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blythspartansafc.co.uk/new_php/?p=11274|title=Spartans sign Pérez|publisher=Blyth Spartans' official website|date=8 August 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027233811/http://blythspartansafc.co.uk/new_php/?p=11274|archivedate=27 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://spfl.co.uk/news/article/berwick-sign-spanish-striker/ |title=Berwick sign Spanish striker |publisher=Scottish Professional Football League |date=8 December 2016 |accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref> Cousin [[María José Pérez (footballer)|María José Pérez]] is a forward for [[Levante UD (women)|Levante UD Femenino]] and the [[Spain women's national football team|Spain women's national team]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Menayo|first1=David|title=María José Pérez: gol con sabor a leyenda canaria|url=http://www.marca.com/2015/10/12/futbol/futbol_femenino/1444650670.html|accessdate=3 September 2016|work=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|date=12 October 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref>

under-21 football team|Spain U21]] | nationalcaps6 = 7 | nationalgoals6 = 0 | club-update = 09:04, 3 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Javier Manquillo Gaitán''' ({{IPA-es|xaˈβjeɾ maŋˈkiʎo}}; born 5 May 1994) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]] for English club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].
==Club career== ===Atlético Madrid=== Born in [[Madrid]], Manquillo started playing football with hometown's [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] alongside his twin brother Víctor, a [[Forward (association football)|forward]]. However, in mid-2007, the club decided to release the latter and the former followed suit, with both signing for neighbouring [[Atlético Madrid]] 48 hours later.<ref>[http://www.mundodeportivo.com/20111208/atletico-madrid/javi-manquillo-el-lateral-que-le-dijo-no-al-real-madrid-por-su-hermano_54240820214.html Javi Manquillo, el lateral que le dijo 'no' al Real Madrid por su hermano (Javi Manquillo, the full back who said 'no' to Real Madrid because of his brother)]; [[Mundo Deportivo]], 8 December 2011 (in Spanish)</ref> In November 2011 he made his unofficial debut with first team, playing in a [[Exhibition game|friendly game]] against [[Zamalek SC]];<ref>[http://www.atleticofans.com/10500/salvio-and-diego-secure-win-over-zamalek/ Salvio and Diego secure win over Zamalek]; Atlético Fans, 10 November 2011</ref> late into the month, he extended his contract until 2016.<ref>[http://www.atleticofans.com/10765/atletico-talent-signs-contract-through-2016/ Atlético talent signs contract through 2016]; Atlético Fans, 30 November 2011</ref>
On 8 December 2011, Manquillo made his official debut for the ''Colchoneros'', starting in a 1–2 away loss against [[Albacete Balompié]] in the [[Copa del Rey]] ([[2011–12 Copa del Rey|1–3 on aggregate]]).<ref>[http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/copa/dieciseisavos/ida/alb_atm/ Adrián evita el naufragio (Adrián prevents shipwreck)]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 8 December 2011 (in Spanish)</ref> He was subsequently an unused [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the matches against [[Real Sociedad]] and [[Málaga CF]], whilst finishing [[2011–12 Segunda División B|the season]] in [[Segunda División B]] with 13 appearances for [[Atlético Madrid B|the B-side]].
On 28 November 2012, again in [[2012–13 Copa del Rey|the domestic cup]], Manquillo appeared in his second game with Atlético's main squad, playing 63 minutes in a 3–0 success at [[Real Jaén]].<ref>[http://www.atleticofans.com/15413/copa-del-rey-atletico-1-0-real-jaen/ Copa del Rey: Atlético 1–0 Real Jaén]; Atlético Fans, 28 November 2012</ref> On 6 December he featured in the 0–1 away defeat against [[FC Viktoria Plzeň]] in the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]].<ref>[http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000356/match=2010014/postmatch/report/index.html#plzen+atletico Plzeň pip Atlético to take top spot]; UEFA, 6 December 2012</ref>
Manquillo's debut in [[La Liga]] came on 9 December 2012, coming on for [[Filipe Luís]] late into the second half of a 6–0 home routing of [[Deportivo de La Coruña]].<ref>[http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=348372&cc=3888 Five-star show from Falcao]; [[ESPN FC]], 9 December 2012</ref> On 3 September of the following year he signed a contract extension with Atlético Madrid, keeping him at the [[Vicente Calderón Stadium]] until 2018.<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2013/09/03/futbol/equipos/atletico/1378213657.html Manquillo, Óliver Torres y Koke, hasta junio de 2018 (Manquillo, Óliver Torres and Koke, until June 2018)]; Marca, 3 September 2013 (in Spanish)</ref>
On 11 February 2014, in the first half of the [[2013–14 Copa del Rey|Spanish Cup semifinal clash]] against Real Madrid, Manquillo was involved in two incidents with [[Cristiano Ronaldo]]: in the early minutes, he conceded a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] which the Portuguese converted in the first goal of an eventual 2–0 win (5–0 on aggregate). Later, after both went for an aerial challenge, he fell headfirst to the ground,<ref>[http://espnfc.com/uk/en/report/387326/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739 Ronaldo spot on for Real]; ESPN FC, 11 February 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.marca.com/2014/02/13/futbol/equipos/atletico/1392285700.html Manquillo estuvo al borde de la tragedia (Manquillo neared tragedy)]; Marca, 13 February 2014 (in Spanish)</ref> going on to be sidelined for more than one month with a [[neck]] injury.<ref>[http://www.marca.com/2014/02/12/futbol/equipos/atletico/1392215993.html Manquillo, un mes con collarín (Manquillo, one month with neck brace)]; Marca, 12 February 2014 (in Spanish)</ref>
On 6 August 2014, Manquillo joined [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in a two-year loan deal with an option to buy after [[2014–15 Premier League|his first season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/168205-reds-complete-manquillo-loan-move|title=Reds complete Manquillo loan move|publisher=Liverpool F.C|date=6 August 2014|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clubatleticodemadrid.com/noticias/acuerdo-con-el-liverpool-para-la-cesion-de-manquillo|title=Acuerdo con el Liverpool para la cesión de Manquillo|trans-title=Agreement with Liverpool for Manquillo's loan|publisher=Atlético Madrid|date=6 August 2014|accessdate=6 August 2014}}</ref> He made his debut 11 days later, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–1 [[Premier League]] win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730043|title=Liverpool 2–1 Southampton|first=David|last=Ornstein|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 August 2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> On 16 September, he won a 93rd-minute penalty in the [[UEFA Champions League]] tie against [[PFC Ludogorets Razgrad]], which [[Steven Gerrard]] converted to make the score 2–1 and win the match;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29209558|title=Liverpool 2–1 Ludogorets Razgrad|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Sam|last=Sheringham|date=16 September 2014|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> the following weekend, in [[2014–15 Football League Cup|the third round]] of the [[Football League Cup]], he converted his [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] attempt against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] as his team prevailed 14–13 following a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29216833|title=Liverpool 2–2 Middlesbrough|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Sam|last=Sheringham|date=23 September 2014|accessdate=23 September 2014}}</ref>
On 6 January 2015, Manquillo provided the [[Assist (football)|assist]] for the first of Gerrard's two goals in a [[2014–15 FA Cup|2–1 win]] at [[A.F.C. Wimbledon]] in the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30620966|title=AFC Wimbledon 1–2 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Phil|last=McNulty|date=6 January 2015|accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref> After featuring in 16 matches during the first part of [[2014–15 Premier League|the season]], he played just three times in 2015, never in the domestic league,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/liverpool/story/2511702/liverpool-considering-ending-javier-manquillo-loan|title=Liverpool considering ending Javier Manquillo loan|publisher=ESPN FC|first=Mike|last=Whalley|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> and Atlético Madrid subsequently confirmed that the loan deal had been terminated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.clubatleticodemadrid.com/noticias/manquillo-will-not-stay-with-liverpool|title=Manquillo will not stay with Liverpool|publisher=Atlético Madrid|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=7 July 2015}}</ref>
On 27 July 2015, Manquillo joined [[Olympique de Marseille]] on a [[2015–16 Ligue 1|season]]-long loan with an option to buy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.om.net/actualites/184513/javier-manquillo-est-olympien|title=Javier Manquillo est Olympien|trans-title=Javier Manquillo is an Olympian|language=French|publisher=Olympique Marseille|date=27 July 2015|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref> On 25 August of the following year, still owned by Atlético, he signed with English club [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] also for [[2016–17 Premier League|one season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.safc.com/news/team-news/2016/august/sunderland-seal-manquillo-deal|title=Sunderland seal Manquillo deal|publisher=Sunderland A.F.C|date=25 August 2016|access-date=25 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.atleticodemadrid.com/noticias/agreement-with-sunderland-for-the-loan-of-manquillo|title=Agreement with Sunderland for the loan of Manquillo|publisher=Atlético Madrid|date=25 August 2016|access-date=25 August 2016}}</ref>
===Newcastle United=== On 21 July 2017, Manquillo signed for Premier League club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40683792|title=Javier Manquillo: Newcastle sign former Liverpool and Sunderland defender|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 July 2017|accessdate=21 July 2017}}</ref>
==International career== Manquillo earned 25 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for [[Spain national youth football team|Spain at youth level]], including seven for [[Spain national under-21 football team|the under-21s]]. He made his debut on 4 September 2014, starting in a 1–0 win in [[Hungary national under-21 football team|Hungary]] for the [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|qualifiers]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mundodeportivo.com/20140904/futbol/0-1-saul-niguez-sella-la-clasificacion-en-el-inicio-de-la-era-celades_54414672594.html|title=0–1: Saúl Ñíguez da la victoria en el estreno de Celades|trans-title=0–1: Saúl Ñíguez gives win in debut of Celades|publisher=Mundo Deportivo|language=es|date=4 September 2014|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref>
