{{EngvarB|date=July 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Christian Atsu | image = 20150331 Mali vs Ghana 039.jpg | image_size = | caption = Atsu playing for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] in March 2015 | fullname = Christian Atsu Twasam<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html |title=Player shirt numbers for 20 Barclays Premier League clubs released |publisher=Premier League |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=9 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809220849/http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html |archivedate=9 August 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|1|10|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Ada Foah]], Ghana | height = 1.65 m<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/4859/Christian-Atsu/overview |title=Christian Atsu: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubnumber = 30 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Feyenoord Ghana|Feyenoord Fetteh]] | youthyears2 = 2009–2011 | youthclubs2 = [[F.C. Porto|Porto]] | years1 = 2011–2013 | clubs1 = [[F.C. Porto|Porto]] | caps1 = 17 | goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2011–2012 | clubs2 = → [[Rio Ave F.C.|Rio Ave]] (loan) | caps2 = 27 | goals2 = 6 | years3 = 2013–2017 | clubs3 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps3 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2013–2014 | clubs4 = → [[Vitesse Arnhem|Vitesse]] (loan) | caps4 = 28 | goals4 = 5 | years5 = 2014–2015 | clubs5 = → [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] (loan) | caps5 = 5 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2015–2016 | clubs6 = → [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] (loan) | caps6 = 0 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2016 | clubs7 = → [[Málaga CF|Málaga]] (loan) | caps7 = 12 | goals7 = 2 | years8 = 2016–2017 | clubs8 = → [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] (loan) | caps8 = 32 | goals8 = 5 | years9 = 2017– | clubs9 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps9 = 52 | goals9 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2012– | nationalteam1 = [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] | nationalcaps1 = 42 | nationalgoals1 = 9 | club-update = 17:32, 16 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 25 January 2016 (UTC) }}
'''Christian Atsu Twasam''' (born 10 January 1992) is a Ghanaian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and the [[Ghana national football team|Ghanaian national team]]. He primarily plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]], although he has also been deployed as an [[Midfielder#Attacking midfielder|attacking midfielder]].
He began his career with [[FC Porto|Porto]], also spending a season on loan at [[Rio Ave F.C.|Rio Ave]]. In 2013, he was signed by Chelsea for £3.5 million, who subsequently loaned him to [[Vitesse Arnhem]], [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] and [[Málaga CF|Málaga]]. After spending the 2016–17 season on loan at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], he completed a permanent transfer to the club in May 2017.
A full international with over 30 caps since his debut in 2012, Atsu has represented Ghana at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] and two [[Africa Cup of Nations]] tournaments. He helped the team finish as runners-up at the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations]], in which he also won Player of the Tournament and Goal of the Tournament.
==Club career== Atsu was born in [[Ada Foah]], [[Greater Accra Region]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=240487|title=Christian Atsu – The newest Black Star|publisher=Ghana Web|date=30 May 2012|accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref>
===Porto===
Atsu arrived at [[FC Porto|Porto]] at the age of 17, finishing his football formation with the club. On 14 May 2011, he was called up by first-team manager [[André Villas-Boas]] for a [[Primeira Liga]] match against [[C.S. Marítimo|Marítimo]], but he did not leave the [[Substitute (association football)|bench]].{{citation needed|date=June 2016}}
As with teammate [[Kelvin Mateus de Oliveira|Kelvin]], Atsu was sent on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to fellow league side [[Rio Ave F.C.|Rio Ave]] for the [[2011–12 Primeira Liga|2011–12 season]]. He made his debut in the competition on 28 August 2011, in a 0–1 home loss against [[S.C. Olhanense|Olhanense]]. On 16 December 2011, Atsu opened the score at [[Estádio da Luz]] against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in the 24th minute, but the hosts eventually won it 5–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more-liga-sagres-news/30481-benfica-cruise-past-rio-ave|title=Benfica cruise past Rio Ave|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=16 December 2011|accessdate=17 December 2011|archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20120125161149/http://www.portugoal.net/index.php/more%2Dliga%2Dsagres%2Dnews/30481%2Dbenfica%2Dcruise%2Dpast%2Drio%2Dave|archive-date=25 January 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
He returned to Porto for the [[2012–13 Primeira Liga|2012–13 campaign]], starting in nine of his league appearances as they won the national championship for the third consecutive time. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sunnews.info/ghana-news/index.php/2018/04/14/christian-atsu-reflects-on-time-at-portuguese-giants-fc-porto/|title=Christian Atsu reflects on time at Portuguese giants FC Porto {{!}} SunNews.info - Ghana News|last=Ayisi|first=Kojo|language=en-US|access-date=2019-01-24}}</ref>
===Chelsea===
On 1 September 2013, Atsu agreed to join [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on a five-year contract, for a reported £3.5 million, being immediately loaned to Dutch club [[Vitesse Arnhem]], for the rest of the 2013–14 season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Christian Atsu: Chelsea sign Porto striker on five-year deal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23923446|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=1 September 2013}}</ref>
====Loan to Vitesse==== On 6 October 2013, Atsu made his debut against [[Feyenoord]] as a substitute, replacing [[Valeri Kazaishvili|Kazaishvili]] in the 77th minute. He went on to providing an assist to [[Mike Havenaar]], but it was not enough to prevent a 2–1 loss for Vitesse.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vitesse 1–2 Feyenoord|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/10/06/netherlands/eredivisie/sbv-vitesse/feyenoord-rotterdam-nv/1478409/|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=Soccerway|date=6 October 2013}}</ref> On 19 October, Atsu made his first start against [[SC Heerenveen]], which ended in a 3–2 win for Vitesse.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vitesse 1–2 Feyenoord|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/10/19/netherlands/eredivisie/sportclub-heerenveen/sbv-vitesse/1478419/|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=Soccerway|date=19 October 2013}}</ref> On 9 November, he converted a penalty for his first goal with Vitesse, against [[FC Utrecht]]; the match ended in a 3–1 win for Vitesse.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vitesse 3–1 Utercht|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/11/09/netherlands/eredivisie/sbv-vitesse/stichting-fc-utrecht/1478445/|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=Soccerway|date=9 November 2013}}</ref>
In total, Atsu played 30 games and scored 5 goals for the Dutch side as they finished 6th in the [[2013–14 Eredivisie#League table|league]] and qualified to the [[2013–14 Eredivisie#European competition|play offs]].
====Loan to Everton==== [[File:Александар Драгович - Aleksandar Dragovic (16684466389).jpg|thumb|Atsu (left) playing for Everton in the [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] match against [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]] on 19 March 2015]] On 13 August 2014, Atsu joined fellow Premier League club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on loan until the end of the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Atsu Deal Complete|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2014/08/13/atsu-deal-complete|work=[[Everton F.C.|Everton]]|date=13 August 2014|accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref> He made his first appearance for the club 10 days later, coming on as an 85th-minute substitute for [[Kevin Mirallas]] in a 2–2 draw with [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] at [[Goodison Park]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bevan|first1=Chris|title=Everton 2–2 Arsenal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28816295|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=23 August 2014}}</ref>
On 21 September 2014, Atsu made his first start in the league against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], which ended in a 2–3 home loss.<ref>{{cite news|title=Everton 2–3 Crystal Palace|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2014/09/21/england/premier-league/everton-football-club/crystal-palace-fc/1703579/|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=Soccerway|date=21 September 2014}}</ref> After his absence due to the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations|Africa Cup of Nations]], Atsu returned to Everton's lineup on 19 February 2015 in a Europa League match against [[BSC Young Boys]], playing out the last five minutes after replacing hat-trick scorer [[Romelu Lukaku]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Romelu Lukaku responded to recent fan criticism with a first Everton hat-trick in a fine Europa League round of 32 first-leg win over Young Boys|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/31523676|work=BBC Sports|date=19 February 2015}}</ref> and came off the bench three days later to set up a late equaliser in a 2–2 draw at home to [[Leicester City]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31475995|title=Everton 2–2 Leicester City|date=2015-02-22|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en-GB}}</ref> On 15 March 2015, in the match against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], he came off the bench with 5 minutes remaining, and provided another an assist to fellow substitute [[Ross Barkley]] for Everton's third goal of a 3–0 home victory.<ref>{{cite news|title=Everton 3 Newcastle 0: McCarthy, Lukaku and Barkley ease Toffees' relegation fears|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/430883/Everton-3-Newcastle-0-Match-report|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=[[Daily Star (British newspaper)|Daily Star]]|date=15 March 2015}}</ref> Following Atsu's impact as a substitute in the above games, he was picked to start the second leg of a Europa League Round of 16 match away to [[Dynamo Kyiv]] on 19 March with regular right-winger Aaron Lennon cup-tied, with Everton leading 2–1 from the first leg. His team were eliminated after losing 5–2 on the night, he was withdrawn in the 65th minute,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31949673 |title=Dynamo Kiev 5–2 Everton |first=Luke |last=Reddy |work=BBC Sport |date=19 March 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> and that was his final first-team appearance for Everton.<ref>{{soccerbase season|61810|2014|accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
====Loan to Bournemouth==== On 29 May 2015, Atsu was loaned to newly promoted Premier League team [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] for the upcoming season, with club Chief Executive Neill Blake calling the deal "a huge coup".<ref>{{cite news|title=Christian Atsu: Chelsea winger joins AFC Bournemouth on loan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32936402|accessdate=29 May 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=29 May 2015}}</ref> He made his debut on 25 August in the second round of the League Cup, starting in a 4–0 win at [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]]. Atsu's only other appearance was in the next round's victory at [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]]; he did not feature in any Bournemouth matchday squad in the league and he was recalled from his loan by Chelsea on 1 January 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea recall Christian Atsu from loan and put him in first-team|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/01/01/chelsea-recall-christian-atsu-from-loan-and-put-him-in-first-team-report-5596145/|accessdate=2 January 2016|work=Metro|date=1 January 2016}}</ref>
====Loan to Málaga====
On 24 January 2016, Atsu gave an interview with the [[BBC World Service]] in which he spoke about leaving Chelsea and his imminent transfer to [[Levante UD|Levante]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Christian Atsu on his Levante transfer|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p03gf8hb|accessdate=25 January 2016|work=BBC World Service|date=24 January 2016}}</ref> The next day, it was confirmed that he would be instead moving to [[Málaga CF|Málaga]] on loan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Christian Atsu leaves Chelsea for Malaga on loan|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10143657/christian-atsu-leaves-chelsea-for-malaga-on-loan|accessdate=25 January 2016|work=Sky Sports|date=25 January 2016}}</ref> On 5 February 2016, Atsu made his debut in the starting eleven and scored in a 3–0 victory over [[Getafe CF]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.in/football/report?gameId=433751 |title=Juanpi and Charles inspire comfortable win for Malaga |date=5 February 2016 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref>
===Newcastle United===
On 31 August 2016, it was confirmed that Christian Atsu had joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on a one-year loan deal with an option to buy clause in the contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2940664/newcastle-complete-loan-deal-for-chelsea-winger-christian-atsu |title=Newcastle complete loan deal for Chelsea winger Christian Atsu |date=31 August 2016 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> On 13 September, his debut for the club came on as a substitute for [[Yoan Gouffran]] in the 61st minute in a 6–0 away victory against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] at [[Loftus Road]], where he provided the assist to [[Aleksandar Mitrović (footballer)|Aleksandar Mitrović]] to earn their fifth goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37282510 |title=Queens Park Rangers 0–6 Newcastle United |date=14 September 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> Atsu scored his first goal for the club in a 1–0 win against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] on 1 October 2016,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37458708|title=Rotherham 0–1 Newcastle |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=1 October 2016|accessdate=4 October 2016}}</ref> followed by further goals against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] and [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan]]. In May 2017 Atsu agreed terms on a permanent switch to Newcastle. He signed a four-year deal at St James' Park and joined the Magpies for £6.2m.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/10879870/chelsea-winger-christian-atsu-agrees-to-join-newcastle|title=Chelsea winger Christian Atsu agrees to join Newcastle|publisher=[[SkySports]]|date=16 May 2017|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:20150331 Mali vs Ghana 112.jpg|thumb|Atsu on the ball in a friendly against [[Mali national football team|Mali]] in [[Paris]] in March 2015]]
Atsu won his first senior [[Cap (sport)|cap]] for [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 1 June 2012 against [[Lesotho national football team|Lesotho]], scoring in the process.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/SportsArchive/artikel.php?ID=240857|title=Atsu makes debut statement|publisher=Ghana Web|date=1 June 2012|accessdate=4 June 2012}}</ref> He was described by the [[BBC]] as an "excellent prospect",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19570312|title=Ghana hails exciting new talent|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|author=Michael Oti Adjei|date=12 September 2012|accessdate=13 September 2012}}</ref> whilst [[ESPN]] added he was "quick and technically impressive", and a potential future star for his national team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/blog/_/name/thescoutsnotebook/id/398?cc=5901|title=World Cup 2014: Ten potential breakout stars|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|last=Atkins|first=Christopher|date=12 June 2013|accessdate=14 June 2013}}</ref>
The following year, he was in the Ghanaian squad for the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations|Africa Cup of Nations in South Africa]]. He started the first match, a 2–2 draw against the [[DR Congo national football team|DR Congo]], and was a substitute in the following 1–0 win over [[Mali national football team|Mali]]. He returned to the starting line-up in the last group match against [[Niger national football team|Niger]] in [[Port Elizabeth]], scoring the second goal of a 3–0 win which put his country into the quarter-finals as group winners.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Ghana 3–0 Niger|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21044464|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=28 January 2013}}</ref> Atsu featured in the rest of Ghana's matches as they came fourth, scoring in their [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] elimination by [[Burkina Faso national football team|Burkina Faso]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Burkina Faso 1–1 Ghana|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21339090|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=6 February 2015}}</ref>
Atsu was selected for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] squad,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/ghana/10810459/Ghana-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|title=Ghana World Cup 2014 squad|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=21 June 2014}}</ref> starting in all the matches as Ghana were eliminated in the group stage.
At the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations]], Atsu scored twice in a 3–0 win over [[Guinea national football team|Guinea]] in the quarter-finals.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hughes|first1=Ian|title=Ghana 3–0 Guinea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30971820|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2015}}</ref> He helped the team to the final, where they lost in a [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] against the [[Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast]]. At the end of the tournament, he was awarded with both the Player of the Tournament award, as well as the Goal of the Tournament award for his strike against Guinea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Neil|title=Everton FC's Christian Atsu named AFCON Player of the Tournament|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-fcs-christian-atsu-named-8605221|accessdate=10 April 2015|work=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=9 February 2015}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Freddie Woodman | image = | image_size = | caption = | fullname = Frederick John Woodman<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html |title=Player shirt numbers for 20 Barclays Premier League clubs released |publisher=Premier League |date=8 August 2015 |accessdate=10 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809220849/http://m.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/article.080815-2015-2016-premier-league-squad-numbers-released.html |archivedate=9 August 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|3|4|df=y}}<ref name="Premier League">{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/10479/Freddie-Woodman/overview |title=Freddy Woodman: Overview |publisher=Premier League |accessdate=8 September 2018}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Croydon]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|order=flip}}<ref name="Premier League"/> | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | clubnumber = 41 | youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2013 |youthclubs1 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | youthyears2 = 2013–2014 |youthclubs2 = [[Newcastle United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Newcastle United]] | years1 = 2014– |clubs1 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] |caps1 = 0 |goals1 = 0<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years2 = 2014 |clubs2 = → [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]] (loan) |caps2 = 0 |goals2 = 0<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years3 = 2015 |clubs3 = → [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] (loan) |caps3 = 11 |goals3 = 0<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years4 = 2017 |clubs4 = → [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] (loan) |caps4 = 14 |goals4 = 0<!-- LEAGUE ONLY --> | years5 = 2018 |clubs5 = → [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] (loan) |caps5 = 5 |goals5 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2012–2013 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] |nationalcaps1 = 2 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2012–2014 |nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] |nationalcaps2 = 16 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2015 |nationalteam3 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] |nationalcaps3 = 6 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2014–2016 |nationalteam4 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] |nationalcaps4 = 16 |nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2016–2017 |nationalteam5 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] |nationalcaps5 = 10 |nationalgoals5 = 0 | nationalyears6 = 2016– |nationalteam6 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] |nationalcaps6 = 6 |nationalgoals6 = 0 | club-update = 19:17, 15 May 2018 (UTC) | ntupdate = 13:00, 11 June 2018 (UTC) }} '''Frederick John Woodman''' (born 4 March 1997) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].
Woodman started his career at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] before moving to the academy set up at [[Newcastle United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Newcastle United]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web |title=Freddie Woodman is the 18-year-old Newcastle goalkeeper being taught by Tim Krul and who had to work 10 times harder to prove himself because his dad is the coach!|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2984816/Freddie-Woodman-18-year-old-Newcastle-goalkeeper-taught-Tim-Krul-work-10-times-harder-prove-dad-coach.html|website=The Daily Mail Online |publisher=The Daily Mail |date=8 March 2015}}</ref> Woodman has represented England up to U21 level, and has won the [[2014 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] and the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] with his country. He received the Golden Glove award for best goalkeeper in the latter tournament.
==Club career== ===Newcastle===
===2014–15 season===
====Loan to Hartlepool United==== On 16 September 2014, Woodman was sent on a month long loan to [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Freddie Woodman: Hartlepool sign Newcastle United keeper|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29222817 |publisher=British Broadcast Corporation |date=16 September 2014}}</ref> to gain experience of being in a first team environment. After six appearances as an unused substitute, Woodman returned to Newcastle.<ref name="chroniclelive1">{{cite web|last=Johns |first=Craig |url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/freddie-woodman-five-things-you-8309544 |title=Freddie Woodman: Five things you may not know about the keeper in line for Tyne-Wear derby debut |publisher=Chronicle Live |date=2014-12-18 |accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref>
===2015–16 season===
====Crawley Town (loan)==== On 29 July 2015, Woodman was sent on another loan spell to [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] for half of the 2015–16 season. His debut match was played on 8 August 2015 in a 1–1 draw against [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Oxford United vs. Crawley Town |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33744437|website=British Broadcasting Corporation |publisher=BBC Sports |date=8 August 2015}}</ref> Freddie Woodman has said "I'm really looking forward to it. It's a massive difference and it takes some getting used to, I'll take this experience back with me and say 'let's not come back here, let's play in the Premier League'." when asked about his loan spell by BBC.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freddie Woodman: On-loan goalkeeper targets Premier League|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33789552 |publisher=British Broadcast Corporation |date=5 August 2015}}</ref> When [[Mark Yates (footballer)|Mark Yates]], the manager of Crawley Town, was asked about signing Woodman he said "We are delighted to have been able to bring one of the best young goalkeepers in the country to the club. The only thing Freddie lacks at the moment is experience in League football and that is what this loan spell with give him. He has all the attributes to become a top-class keeper and I have to thank [[Steve McClaren]], Andy Woodman and everyone at Newcastle for letting us have Freddie for the first half of the season" during an interview with The Football League.<ref>{{cite web|title=Crawley Town manager Mark Yates delighted with capture of Freddie Woodman|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/2015/crawley-town-manager-mark-yates-delighted-to-sign-freddie-woodman-2581533.aspx |publisher=The Football League |date=30 July 2015}}</ref>
In October 2015, Newcastle United recalled Woodman from his loan at Crawley Town after first choice keeper [[Tim Krul]] suffered a season ending knee injury, Woodman made 12 appearances during his spell with Crawley.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/newcastle-set-recall-freddie-woodman-10237520|title=Newcastle set to recall Freddie Woodman from loan stint at Crawley after Tim Krul injury|first=Lee|last=Ryder|date=11 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3268524/Newcastle-United-s-Tim-Krul-miss-rest-season-cruciate-ligament-damage-suffering-injury-playing-Holland.html|title=Krul to miss rest of the season as Woodman returns from Crawley loan|publisher=}}</ref>
===2016–17 season===
====Kilmarnock (loan)==== On 9 January 2017, Woodman moved on loan to [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] for the remainder of the season, along with Newcastle teammates [[Callum Roberts (footballer)|Callum Roberts]] and [[Sean Longstaff]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Player Announcement|url=http://kilmarnockfc.co.uk/Article?id=4830|publisher=Kilmarnock F.C.|date=9 January 2017|accessdate=9 January 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 21 January 2017, as Kilmarnock lost 1–0 against [[Hamilton Academical F.C.|Hamilton Academical]] in the [[Scottish Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Kilmarnock 0–1 Hamilton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38620259|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Wilson|first=Richard|date=21 January 2017|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref> Woodman played regularly for Kilmarnock, keeping five clean sheets in 15 appearances.<ref name = "u20 world cup"/> He left the club before the end of the season to play in the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]].<ref name = "u20 world cup">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39850045 |title=Kilmarnock: Freddie Woodman will not feature again after England selection |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=8 May 2017 |accessdate=8 May 2017}}</ref>
===2017–18 season=== Woodman made his debut for Newcastle in an [[FA Cup]] tie with [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Newcastle United 3 Luton Town 1|url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/matches/first-team/2017-18/newcastle-united-v-luton-town|publisher=Newcastle United F.C.|date=6 January 2018|accessdate=18 February 2018}}</ref>
====Aberdeen (loan)==== Woodman was loaned to [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] on 31 January 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42892606 |title=Aberdeen sign goalkeeper Freddie Woodman and striker Sam Cosgrove |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Woodman won the [[2014 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship]] with England, conceding two goals in 4 games and saving a penalty in the final of the tournament against the [[Netherlands national under-17 football team|Netherlands]].<ref name="chroniclelive1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/jul/freddie-woodman-joins-crawley-town-on-loan-300715 |title=Freddie Woodman signs for Crawley Town on loan from Newcastle - England |publisher=The FA |date=2015-07-30 |accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref> In the 2014–15 season Woodman played up an age group with the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] side.<ref name="thefa1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/mar/freddie-woodman-on-worker-ten-times-harder-at-newcastle-united-090315 |title=England U18 keeper Freddie Woodman says Hartlepool loan spell and dad's tutelage have prepared him for Newcastle United first team - England |publisher=The FA |date=2015-03-09 |accessdate=2015-08-14}}</ref> Woodman was a member of the England squad for the [[2016 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]], starting in the semi-final defeat against [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italy]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/jul/21/italy-report-210716|title=England Under-19s' Euro dreams ended by Italy in Semi-Final|date= 21 July 2016 |publisher=Football Association|accessdate=11 July 2017 }}</ref>
On 6 October 2016, Woodman made his debut at [[England national under-21 football team|Under-21]] level against [[Kazakhstan national under-21 football team|Kazakhstan]] keeping a clean sheet in the process.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/oct/08/freddie-woodman-interview-081016|title=Freddie Woodman's 'Fantastic night' in Kazakhstan|date= 8 October 2016 |publisher=Football Association|accessdate=11 July 2017 }}</ref> He was selected in the [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] squad for the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]],<ref name = "u20 world cup"/> where he won the Golden Glove Award for the tournament's best goalkeeper,<ref name="Golden glove">{{cite web|title=FIFA U-20 World Cup Korea Republic 2017 - Awards|url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/awards/index.html|publisher=FIFA.com|date=11 June 2017|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> and saved a penalty in the final against [[Venezuela national under-20 football team|Venezuela]] which England won 1–0.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40237981|title=Under-20 World Cup: England beat Venezuela in final|date= 11 June 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 June 2017 }}</ref>
==Personal life== He is the son of former Northampton Town goalkeeper [[Andy Woodman]] and his godfather is former England international defender and current England manager [[Gareth Southgate]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/fred-woodman-make-battle-number-10242818|title=Why Fred Woodman is about to make the battle for the number one spot interesting at Newcastle United|first=Lee|last=Ryder|date=12 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref>

national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 6 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | club-update = 10:22, 14 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Jacob Kai Murphy''' (born 24 February 1995) is an English professional footballer who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].
Murphy made his first-team debut for [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] in an [[FA Cup]] match against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in January 2014. He has also played on loan for [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] and [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]]. He is the twin brother of professional footballer [[Josh Murphy]]. The brothers are nephews of former [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] utility player [[Tommy Parkin]].<ref name=parkinsNephews>{{cite news | last = Roger | first = James | title = Who is Jacob Murphy? Five things you need to know about Coventry City FC's new signing | newspaper = Coventry Telegraph | location = Coventry | language = English | date = 15 August 2015 | url = https://www.coventrytelegraph.net/sport/football/football-news/who-jacob-murphy-five-things-9862814 | access-date = 18 April 2018}}</ref>
== Senior career == === Norwich City === Murphy was born in [[Wembley]], London.<ref name="Hugman"/> Along with his twin brother, Josh, he first played football together from the age of seven,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2013-14/oct/barclays-u21-jacob-murphy-interview.html |title=Barclays U21s: Murphy's twin ambition for Norwich |publisher=Premier League Official Website |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=30 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229135507/http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2013-14/oct/barclays-u21-jacob-murphy-interview.html |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and eventually they both joined [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] as under-12s in 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dream chance for nine Norwich City hopefuls|url=http://www.pinkun.com/norwich-city/dream_chance_for_nine_norwich_city_hopefuls_1_847433|publisher=The Pink UN|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> It was announced on 31 March 2011 that the duo were to join the club's academy ahead of a new season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dream chance for nine Norwich City hopefuls|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/dream_chance_for_nine_norwich_city_hopefuls_1_847433|publisher=Eastern Daily Press 24|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
Murphy was a part of the Norwich City youth team which won the [[2012–13 FA Youth Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Rik Sharma |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2324979/Norwichs-twin-wingers-Josh-Jacob-Murphy-ready-cause-havoc-Premier-League.html|title=Norwich's twin wingers Josh and Jacob Murphy are ready to cause havoc in the Premier League | Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk|date=2013-05-15|accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref> He signed his first professional contract for Norwich City on 4 January 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/twins_jacob_and_josh_murphy_sign_professional_contracts_with_norwich_city_1_1783241 |title=Twins Jacob and Josh Murphy sign professional contracts with Norwich City -Norwich City FC – Eastern Daily Press |publisher=Edp24.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-09-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphy-twins-sign-pro-579399.aspx |title=MURPHY TWINS SIGN PRO |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=4 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229132346/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphy-twins-sign-pro-579399.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> In December 2013, he signed a three-year contract with the club.<ref name="TheDuoatNorwichCity">{{cite news|title=Norwich City twins Josh and Jacob Murphy sign new long-term deals at the club|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/norwich_city_twins_josh_and_jacob_murphy_sign_new_long_term_deals_at_the_club_1_3143370|publisher=Eastern Daily Press 24|date=23 December 2013|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
Murphy made his professional debut in a [[FA Cup]] match against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on 4 January 2014.<ref name="debut">{{cite web|title = Norwich 1 – 1 Fulham|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25531897|publisher = BBC Sport|accessdate = 4 January 2014}}</ref> Murphy made his first Norwich City appearance in the 2014–15 season, where he provided an assist for his twin brother, Josh, to score in a 3–1 win over [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] in the second round of the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City 3 – 1 Crawley Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28847093|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 August 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
=== Loan Spells === On 7 February 2014, he joined [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on loan which began on 8 February, and lasted until 8 March 2014<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/news/article/murphytojoinonloan-1346480.aspx |title=Murphy To Join On Loan |publisher=Swindon Town FC |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=7 February 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229143958/http://www.swindontownfc.co.uk/news/article/murphytojoinonloan-1346480.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Murphy made his debut for the club on 8 February 2014, when he came on as a second-half substitute for [[Dany N'Guessan]], in a 3–2 win over [[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Port Vale 2–3 Swindon Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25994416|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 February 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> After making six appearances, Murphy returned to Norwich City after Swindon Town delayed their decision to extend his loan spell further.<ref>{{cite news|title=Robins delay Murphy decision|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11065/9195912/robins-delay-murphy-decision|publisher=Sky Sports|date=4 March 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
On 27 March 2014, Murphy joined [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] on loan for the remainder of the [[2013–14 Football League Two|2013–14]] season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southendunited.co.uk/news/article/270314-murphy-joins-southend-united-1450073.aspx |title=News: Jacob Murphy joins Blues on loan |publisher=Southend United F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=27 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229145310/http://www.southendunited.co.uk/news/article/270314-murphy-joins-southend-united-1450073.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> He made his Southend United debut days later, when he came on as a substitute and provided a winning goal in a 1–0 win over [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Southend United 1 – 0 Torquay United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26694175|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 March 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140331-jacob-murphy-southend-united-norwich-city-1457795.aspx |title=MURPHY SETTLING IN |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=31 March 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229145236/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140331-jacob-murphy-southend-united-norwich-city-1457795.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club and provided an assist in a 3–1 win over [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]] on 18 April 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rochdale 0 – 3 Southend United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26983358|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 April 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> He went on to make eight appearances for the club, including in the play-offs, but was unable to help the club get promoted to League One.
On 3 November 2014, he joined [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on loan until 2 February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jacob Murphy: Blackpool sign Norwich City winger on loan|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29886611|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 November 2014|date=3 November 2014}}</ref> He scored on his debut two days later after joining the club, in a 2–2 draw against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Fulham 2 – 2 Blackpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29813396|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 November 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> A few weeks later, he scored again on 22 November 2014, in a 1–1 draw against [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackpool 1–1 Bolton Wanderers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30065001|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 November 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> His performances at Blackpool earned him November's Wonga Player of the Month award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/news/article/murphy-wins-november-award-2131756.aspx |title=Murphy Wins November Award |publisher=Blackpool F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=8 December 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229212320/http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/news/article/murphy-wins-november-award-2131756.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The following month, Murphy caused controversy when he posted an image on social media application [[Snapchat]] with the caption "We are going to lose... Again", which mocked the club's recent league form.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blackpool's Jacob Murphy apologises for posting image|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30628138|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> Murphy issued an apology via the club's official website, admitting it was an unprofessional and foolish thing to do; however, [[Lee Clark (footballer)|Lee Clark]] vowed to investigate this matter before taking action.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/news/article/murphy-issues-statement-2172059.aspx |title=Murphy Issues Statement |publisher=Blackpool F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=29 December 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229212400/http://www.blackpoolfc.co.uk/news/article/murphy-issues-statement-2172059.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Blackpool cut short his loan deal on 31 December.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jacob Murphy: Blackpool cut short Norwich winger's loan spell|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30643574|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 December 2014|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>
After his loan spell at Blackpool came to an end, Murphy joined [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] on a month-long loan.<ref>{{cite news|title=Murphy wings into Scunthorpe|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11065/9636997/murphy-wings-into-scunthorpe|publisher=Sky Sports|date=8 January 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> Two days later on 10 January 2015, he made his Scunthorpe United debut, making his first start, where he provided an assist for [[Tom Hopper (footballer)|Tom Hopper]], who also making his debut, in a 4–1 win over [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scunthorpe-united.co.uk/news/article/report-walsall-1-4-iron-2194299.aspx |title=REPORT: WALSALL 1–4 IRON |publisher=Scunthorpe United |date=10 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110191902/http://www.scunthorpe-united.co.uk/news/article/report-walsall-1-4-iron-2194299.aspx |archivedate=10 January 2015 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> After making three appearance for the club, Murphy's loan spell with Scunthorpe United came to an end.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scunthorpe-united.co.uk/news/article/attention-turns-to-swindon-2264925.aspx|title=ATTENTION TURNS TO SWINDON|publisher=Scunthorpe United F.C.|date=12 February 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512153023/http://www.scunthorpe-united.co.uk/news/article/attention-turns-to-swindon-2264925.aspx|archivedate=12 May 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
After another loan spell came to an end, Murphy joined another League One club, but this time it was [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/colchester-united-norwich-city-jacob-murphy-2332809.aspx|title=Murphy Arrives On Loan|publisher=Colchester United F.C.|date=14 March 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317051939/http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/colchester-united-norwich-city-jacob-murphy-2332809.aspx|archivedate=17 March 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Murphy made his Colchester United debut on 14 March 2015, making his first start as a right wing, in a 3–2 loss against [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Colchester United 2 – 3 Crawley Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31776224|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 March 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> Murphy then scored in the next game against [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] on 17 March 2015, which Colchester United won 2–0.<ref>{{cite news|title=Colchester United 2 – 0 Yeovil Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31809896|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 March 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> Murphy scored two goals in two games in three days against Port Vale<ref>{{cite news|title=Port Vale 1 – 2 Colchester United|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32081121|publisher=BBC Sport|date=3 April 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> and [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Colchester United 3 – 1 Barnsley|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32111201|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 April 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> The last two games of the season saw Murphy scored in a 1–1 draw against Swindon Town<ref>{{cite news|title=Colchester United 1 – 1 Swindon Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32390923|publisher=BBC Sport|date=28 April 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> and then helped the club survive relegation when they beat [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/norwich-city-loan-round-up-5-may-2015-2440505.aspx|title=LOAN ROUND-UP: MURPHY AIDS COLCHESTER SURVIVAL|publisher=Norwich City F.C.|date=5 May 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710165503/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/norwich-city-loan-round-up-5-may-2015-2440505.aspx|archivedate=10 July 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 14 August 2015, Murphy signed for [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on a season-long loan deal. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/33943395|title=Jacob Murphy: Coventry City sign Norwich City striker on loan|date=14 August 2015|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref> He had a successful full season out on loan, scoring 10 times in 42 games, with nine of those goals coming in the league.
=== Return to Norwich City === Murphy scored his first goal for Norwich in a 4–1 win over [[Blackburn Rovers]] on 6 August 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36929751 |title=Blackburn 1–4 Norwich |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=6 August 2016 |accessdate=8 August 2016}}</ref> His first full season at Norwich yielded 10 goals in 40 games, including nine in the league.
=== Newcastle United === Murphy signed for [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] for an undisclosed fee on 19 July 2017. He cited Newcastle United as his boyhood team and stated that it was his dream to represent the club. Murphy's parents were born in the local area and he has family members from Newcastle's neighbouring town [[Gateshead]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.canaries.co.uk/News/2017/july/jacob-joins-newcastle/|title=Welcome to Norwich City Football Club Jacob Murphy completes Newcastle move|access-date=2017-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/latest-news/magpies-confirm-jacob-murphy-signing|title=Magpies confirm Murphy signing|website=Newcastle United Football Club}}</ref> Murphy scored his first goal for Newcastle in a 3–1 loss to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] on 20 January 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Manchester City 3–1 Newcastle United|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42672232|first=Michael|last=Emons|date=20 January 2018|accessdate=20 January 2018|publisher=BBC Sports}}</ref>
===West Bromwich Albion===
On 31 January 2019, Murphy joined [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47071573|title=West Brom: Jefferson Montero, Jacob Murphy and Stefan Johansen join on loan |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=31 January 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref>
== International career == Murphy was called up to the [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]]s in October 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/england-u-18s-call-for-josh-murphy-422113.aspx |title=ENGLAND U-18S CALL FOR MURPHY TWINS |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=11 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229140134/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/england-u-18s-call-for-josh-murphy-422113.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and made his debut in a 2–0 win over [[Italy national under-18 football team|Italy U18]]s on 24 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphys-shine-for-young-lions-486236.aspx |title=MURPHYS SHINE FOR YOUNG LIONS |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=14 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229140056/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphys-shine-for-young-lions-486236.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
In November 2012, Murphy was called up by [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/february2013-call-ups-611887.aspx |title=TETTEY GETS NORWAY CALL |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=22 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229140859/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/february2013-call-ups-611887.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> His debut came in a 1-0 win over [[Finland national under-19 football team|Finland U19]]s on 13 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/round-up-feb-2013-642705.aspx |title=INTERNATIONAL ROUND-UP |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=7 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229141235/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/round-up-feb-2013-642705.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
In late 2014, Murphy was called up by [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]]s after his brother Josh withdrew from the squad<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/england-u20-jacob-murphy-replaces-twin-josh-2001697.aspx |title=ENGLAND U20: JACOB MURPHY REPLACES TWIN JOSH |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=5 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229142931/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/england-u20-jacob-murphy-replaces-twin-josh-2001697.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and made his debut in a 3–2 win over [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands U20]]s on 14 October 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20141014-international-round-up-2016359.aspx |title=ROUND-UP: CANARIES ON INTERNATIONAL DUTY |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=14 October 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229143651/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20141014-international-round-up-2016359.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
In 2017 Jacob Murphy was called up to [[England U21s]] squad. In his first game for [[England U21s]] he scored 2 goals in a 3–0 win over Iceland U21s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pinkun.com/norwich-city/norwich-city-winger-jacob-murphy-hits-double-for-england-under-21s-in-behind-closed-doors-friendly-1-5056606|title=Norwich City winger Jacob Murphy hits double for England Under-21s in behind-closed-doors friendly|last=Armstrong|first=Mark|work=Pink Un – Norwich City Football Club News|access-date=2017-06-11}}</ref> Jacob Murphy scored his third goal for [[England national under-21 football team|Englands U21s]] on 22 June 2017, when he came on as a substitute to score a tap in and put the U21s through to the semi finals of the 2017 [[UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.canaries.co.uk/News/2017/june/murphy-goals-puts-england-through/|title=Murphy strike helps England through to semi-finals|publisher=Norwich City Football Club|access-date=2017-06-23}}</ref>
== Personal life == The twins talked about their close bonds and being there for each other.<ref name="TheDuoatNorwichCity"/> Their parents and his younger brother lives in [[Downham Market]] and run their Arbuckles restaurant, near Downham Market. Their father, John, works as an assistant principal at Downham Market Academy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mum is the word for Norwich City starlet Josh Murphy|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/mum_is_the_word_for_norwich_city_starlet_josh_murphy_1_2809818|publisher=Eastern Daily Press 24|date=26 September 2013|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> While on the pitch, [[Chris Hughton]], manager at the time, told the twins to wear different coloured boots so that he could tell them apart.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City boss Chris Hughton baffled by twin starlets|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/359212/Norwich-boss-Chris-Hughton-baffled-by-twin-starlets|publisher=Daily Star|date=7 January 2014|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City's Murphy twins wear different boots to help boss|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25685868|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2014|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref>

{{Infobox football biography | name = Jamie Sterry | image = | fullname = Jamie Michael Sterry{{cite web |title=Squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/465277 |publisher=Premier League |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=26 September 2017}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1995|11|21|df=y}}{{cite web |title=Jamie Sterry |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/jamie-sterry-248951//|publisher=11v11 |accessdate=21 September 2017}} | birth_place = [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], England | height = {{height|m=1.80}} | currentclub = [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]]
(on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]) | clubnumber = 32 | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Right back]] | youthyears1 = 2011–2016 | youthclubs1 = [[Newcastle United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Newcastle United]] | years1 = 2015– | clubs1 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps1 = 3 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2016–2017 | clubs2 = → [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] (loan) | caps2 = 16 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018 | clubs3 = → [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] (loan) | caps3 = 9 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2019- | clubs4 = → [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] (loan) | caps4 = 0 | goals4 = 0 | club-update = 09:15, 26 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Jamie Michael Sterry''' (born 21 November 1995) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right back]] for [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]], on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. ==Career== Sterry began his career with [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], where he progressed through the youth ranks at [[St James' Park]] and signed a professional contract in July 2015. He made his [[Premier League]] debut on 15 May 2016, coming on as an 84th-minute substitute in place of [[Moussa Sissoko]] during a 5–1 home win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240333 |title=Newcastle United 5–1 Tottenham Hotspur |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 May 2016 |accessdate=27 May 2016}} On 31 August 2016, he joined [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on loan until January. Sterry scored his first professional goal for Coventry in an [[FA Cup]] tie against [[Morecambe F.C.|Morecambe]] on 6 November 2016.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37813961 |title=Morecambe 1-1 Coventry |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=6 November 2016 |accessdate=7 November 2016}} On 31 January 2018, Sterry joined [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite news|title=Crewe Complete Loan Signing Of Newcastle Defender Sterry|url=https://www.crewealex.net/news/2018/january/crewe-complete-loan-signing-of-newcastle-defender/|accessdate=12 April 2018|work=CreweAlex.net|date=31 January 2018}} He made his Crewe debut on 3 February 2018 at [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]]. He returned to Crewe for a further loan spell in January 2019.{{cite news |title=Jamie Sterry: Newcastle United full-back rejoins Crewe Alexandra on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47015587 |accessdate=26 January 2019 |work=BBC |date=26 January 2019}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 7 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=J. {{for|the Newcastle United football player|Callum Roberts (footballer)}} {{BLP sources|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Callum Roberts | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Professor Callum Roberts.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = | workplaces = [[University of York]] | patrons = | alma_mater = [[University of York]] | thesis_title = Aspects of coral reef fish community structure in the Saudi Arabian Red Sea and on the Great Barrier Reef | thesis_url = http://ethos.bl.uk/OrderDetails.do?uin=uk.bl.ethos.374194 | thesis_year = 1986 | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Callum Michael Roberts''' is a [[marine conservation]] biologist, [[oceanographer]], author, research scholar at the [[University of York]], England.<ref>{{cite web|title=Callum Roberts|url=http://www.york.ac.uk/environment/our-staff/callum-roberts/|publisher=The University of York|accessdate=8 October 2010}}</ref>
==Career== Roberts' work examines the [[Ecological footprint|impact]] of human activity on [[marine ecosystem]]s, particularly [[coral reef]]s. In [[St. Lucia]] and [[Saba]] in the Caribbean, he has studied the effects of [[marine reserve]]s closed to all fishing. His studies revealed both the scale of human impacts on the sea, and the means of protecting [[marine ecosystem]]s from such effects. He is now working to gain a wider acceptance for marine reserves, including in Britain and Europe where he is advising [[fishermen]] on how to promote the concept within the [[Fishing industry|industry]] and to politicians.
Callum has served on a US National Research Council Committee on [[United States National System of Marine Protected Areas|Marine Protected Areas]] and has also been a member of the Marine Reserves Working Group, headed up by Jane Lubchenco, Steve Gaines and [[Steve Palumbi]] at the [[National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis]] in Santa Barbara. With this group he sought to develop a more robust theoretical underpinning for the design and implementation of marine reserves.
In parallel with work on reserves, Callum has also been active with the Coral Reef Fish Specialist Group of the [[World Conservation Union]] (IUCN). With colleagues, he has developed global maps of the [[biodiversity]] [[Range (biology)|distribution]] of [[Coral reef fish|reef fish]]es and other faunal groups. These maps have revealed that marine species are more at risk of global [[extinction]] than previously believed. Many have small geographic ranges and life history characteristics that render them vulnerable to extinction. However, the maps also show ways to prioritise conservation investment into areas where those resources could be most effective.
He was awarded a Pew fellowship in marine conservation in 2000 to tackle obstacles to implementing marine reserves, and in 2001 he was awarded a Hardy fellowship in conservation biology at [[Harvard University]]. Roberts is also an active supporter of the [[Deep Sea Conservation Coalition]].
Since 2011 Roberts has written occasional opinion editorials for ''The Guardian''<ref>{{Cite web|title = Callum Roberts|url = https://www.theguardian.com/profile/callum-roberts|website = the Guardian|access-date = 2016-01-22}}</ref> on various marine conservation topics, including [[overfishing]].<ref>{{Cite news|title = We knew fish catches were too high. But it’s much worse than we thought|url = https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jan/21/fish-stocks-low-worse-official-figures|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2016-01-21|access-date = 2016-01-22|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB}}</ref> He also appeared in the documentary film, [[The End of the Line (2009 film)|The End of the Line]] (2009).
==IUCN Database==
Roberts has also played a major role in creating a global database of coral reef fish biodiversity, in collaboration with members of the IUCN Coral Reef Fish Specialist Group, Chaired by Dr Don McAllister (Ocean Voice International) and Patty Almada-Villela. The project has significantly advanced understanding of the global patterns and determinants of marine biological diversity and provided urgently needed information to establish and guide conservation priorities for the tropical [[Ecosystem|marine environment]].
==Other work==
1999-2003. Member of editorial board of Conservation Biology, published by the Society for Conservation Biology.
1997-2000. Member of Editorial board of journal Animal Conservation, published by Cambridge University Press.
1996. Senior editor of the proceedings of a symposium: “Marine reserves: Function and Design” held at the 8th International Coral Reef Symposium, Panama.
1991-1996. Co-editor of Reef Encounter, Newsletter of the International Society for Reef Studies.

{{BLP sources|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Achraf Lazaar | fullname = | image = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|1|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Casablanca]], [[Morocco]] | height = {{height|meters=1.84}} | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Left back]] | currentclub = [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]
(on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]) | clubnumber = 38 | youthclubs1 = [[Raja Casablanca]] | youthclubs2 = [[A.S. Varese 1910|Varese]] | youthyears1 = | youthyears2 = 2009–2012 | years1 = 2012–2014 | clubs1 = [[A.S. Varese 1910|Varese]] | caps1 = 37 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014–2016 | clubs2 = [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]] | caps2 = 73 | goals2 = 3 | years3 = 2016– | clubs3 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps3 = 4 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2017–2018 | clubs4 = → [[Benevento Calcio|Benevento]] (loan) | caps4 = 9 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2019– | clubs5 = → [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] (loan)| caps5 = 2 | goals5 = 0 | nationalteam1 = [[Morocco national football team|Morocco]] | nationalyears1 = 2014– | nationalcaps1 = 17 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 10:07, 27 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:16, 2 November 2017 (UTC) }} '''Achraf Lazaar''' ({{lang-ar|أشرف لزعر}}; born 22 January 1992) is a [[Morocco|Moroccan]] international [[association football|footballer]], who plays as a [[Midfielder|left midfielder]] or [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|left back]] for [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C. |Sheffield Wednesday]] on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. == Club career == Born in [[Casablanca]], Lazaar moved to [[Italy]] with his parents in 2003. He began his football career with [[A.S. Varese 1910|Varese]]'s youth system, at the age of fifteen. He went on to make his senior debut with the team in [[Serie B]], in 2012, immediately emerging as one of the most interesting prospects from the small Lombardian team.{{cite news |url=http://www3.varesenews.it/sport/lazaar-corre-per-realizzare-il-suo-sogno-in-a-con-il-varese-271601.html |publisher=Varese News |accessdate=13 March 2014 |language=Italian |title=Lazaar corre per realizzare il suo sogno: "In A con il Varese" |trans-title=Lazaar runs to realize his dream: "Serie A with Varese" |date=19 September 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140119001952/http://www3.varesenews.it/sport/lazaar-corre-per-realizzare-il-suo-sogno-in-a-con-il-varese-271601.html |archive-date=2014-01-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In January 2014, he was signed by top of [[Serie B]] [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]], on loan with the option to make the move permanent by the end of the season. Initially signed as an understudy to the more experienced [[Fabio Daprelà]], Lazaar immediately gained a starting spot thanks to his impressive performances. He was later permanently signed by Palermo and confirmed as part of the club's 2014–15 squad. On 28 August 2016, Lazaar joined [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on a five-year deal.{{cite web|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20160828/lazaar-arrives-at-st-james-park_2281670_5842956|title=Lazaar Arrives At St. James' Park|work=nufc.co.uk|date=28 August 2016}} He made his debut in a 2–0 win in the [[EFL Cup]] against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 20 September 2016.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37346000| title=Newcastle 2–0 Wolves |publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=20 September 2016 |accessdate=21 September 2016}} His league debut took place when he came on as a 72nd-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Yoan Gouffran]] against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on 15 October 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37593786|title=Newcastle United 3–1 Brentford|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 October 2016|access-date=17 July 2017}} On 31 August 2017 Lazaar returned to Italy with a loan to [[Benevento Calcio|Benevento]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/it/notizie/calciomercato-benevento-doppio-colpo-sul-gong-lazaar-e/1cizvuefcrs1t1dsv80ixj7grd|title=Lazaar a Benevento|website=goal.com|date=31 August 2017|accessdate= 31 August 2017}} On 31 January 2019 Lazaar joined [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/11624144/west-brom-loan-jacob-murphy-sheffield-wednesday-sign-rolando-aarons-and-achraf-lazaar|title=Newcastle Trio Leave On Loan|publisher=Sky Sports|date=31 January 2019|accessdate= 31 January 2019}} == International career == Having been born in Morocco Lazaar is eligible to play for [[Morocco national football team|Morocco]] by birth, but until 2015 was ineligible to play for [[Italy national football team|Italy]] despite having been raised there. He holds [[Italian nationality law|Italian citizenship]] since April 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mediagol.it/palermo/palermo-achraf-lazaar-acquisisce-cittadinanza-italiana/|title=Palermo: Achraf Lazaar acquisisce cittadinanza italiana|date=2015-04-07|work=Mediagol|access-date=2018-05-28|language=it-IT}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.varesenews.it/2015/05/lazaar-diventa-cittadino-italiano/367620/|title=Lazaar diventa cittadino italiano|date=2015-05-04|work=VareseNews|access-date=2018-05-28|language=it-IT}} He had originally never stated a clear preference to represent Morocco or Italy, instead declaring he would play for the first international team that showed a genuine interest in calling him up. His impressive [[Serie B]] performances with Palermo brought interest from the Moroccan national team, who called him up for a friendly match against [[Mozambique national football team|Mozambique]] on 23 May 2014 and ended in a 4–0 win, during which he made his first senior international appearance. == Career statistics == {{updated|match played 20 May 2018}}{{cite web|title=A. {{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Rolando Aarons | image = Newcastle United vs Watford, 19 September 2015 (17).JPG | caption = Aarons in 2015 | fullname = Rolando Aarons{{cite web|title=Barclays Premier League: notification of shirt numbers|url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/squad-lists/Barclays-Premier-League-Squad-Numbers-2014-15.pdf|publisher=Premier League|format=PDF|page=14|accessdate=16 August 2014}} | height = {{height|m=1.75}}{{cite news|title=Rolando Aarons|url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/AcademyPlayerProfile/0,,10278~2825528,00.html|publisher=Newcastle United FC|accessdate=18 March 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140218015253/http://www.nufc.co.uk/page/Teams/AcademyPlayerProfile/0,,10278~2825528,00.html|archivedate=18 February 2014|df=dmy-all}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1995|11|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]], Jamaica | currentclub = [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]]
(on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]) | clubnumber = 39 | position = [[Midfielder#Winger|Winger]] | youthyears1 = 2009–2012 | youthclubs1 = [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] | youthyears2 = 2012–2014 | youthclubs2 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | years1 = 2014– | clubs1 = [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] | caps1 = 22 | goals1 = 2 | years2 = 2018 | clubs2 = → [[Hellas Verona F.C.|Hellas Verona]] (loan) | caps2 = 11 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018 | clubs3 = → [[FC Slovan Liberec|Slovan Liberec]] (loan) | caps3 = 12 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2019– | clubs4 = → [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] (loan) | caps4 = 8 | goals4 = 1 | nationalyears1 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps1 = 5 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | club-update = 20:17, 13 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 2 April 2016 }} '''Rolando Aarons''' (born 16 November 1995) is a [[Jamaica|Jamaican]] born [[England national under-20 football team|England U-20]] international [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on loan from [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. == Club career == === Newcastle United === Aarons joined Newcastle United in 2012 after being released by his home town club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].{{cite news|last1=Cameron|first1=Neil|title=Newcastle United star Rolando Aarons' fightback after being dumped Bristol City shows real character|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-united-star-rolando-aarons-7738632|accessdate=10 September 2014|newspaper=[[Evening Chronicle]]|date=9 September 2014}} He made his reserve team debut on 8 February 2013 against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and scored in his second reserve game against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] 17 days later.{{cite news|title=Reserves Fixtures 2012/13|url=http://www.nufc.com/html/2012-13html/reserves-prem.html|publisher=Newcastle United FC|date=15 July 2013|accessdate=6 January 2014}} Aarons travelled with the Newcastle squad to their game against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. He was not included in the matchday squad as the Magpies lost 1–0. Reserves teammate [[Ľubomír Šatka]] also travelled with the squad for the first time. On 1 April 2014, Aarons signed a professional contract with Newcastle United.{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140401/aarons-pens-professional-deal_2281670_3743603 | title=Aarons Pens Professional Deal | publisher=Newcastle United | date=1 April 2014 | accessdate=1 April 2014}} ====2014–15 season==== Aarons had an impressive pre-season prior to the [[2014–15 Newcastle United F.C. season|2014–15 season]], scoring one goal and creating one assist in the [[2014 Schalke 04 Cup]] against [[Bundesliga]] team [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke]]. Shortly after, he was allocated the number 16 shirt.{{cite press release | url=http://www.nufc.co.uk/articles/20140807/squad-numbers-announced_2281670_4058068 | title=Squad Numbers Announced | publisher=Newcastle United | date=7 August 2014 | accessdate=7 August 2014}} On 17 August 2014, he made his [[Premier League]] debut in their first match of the campaign, replacing [[Yoan Gouffran]] for the final 16 minutes of a 2–0 home defeat to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Saj|title=Newcastle 0–2 Man City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730044|accessdate=17 August 2014|work=[[BBC Sport]]|date=17 August 2014}} He scored his first senior goal in the 3–3 draw with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 30 August. He also set up teammate [[Mike Williamson (footballer)|Mike Williamson]] for Newcastle's third goal in the same match, striking the post with his own effort. His contribution to the match described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as "thrillingly incisive".{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Louise|title=Crystal Palace's Wilfried Zaha scores last-gasp equaliser at Newcastle|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/aug/30/newcastle-crystal-palace-premier-league-match-report|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=30 August 2014}} Aarons came back from [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] duty with a hamstring injury; scans in mid-September determined that it would take around six weeks for the injury to heal.{{cite news|last1=Ryder|first1=Lee|title=Injury woes for Newcastle United as Rolando Aarons could be out for longer than feared|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/injury-woes-newcastle-united-rolando-7778368|accessdate=18 September 2014|newspaper=[[Evening Chronicle]]|date=16 September 2014}} On 29 October, Aarons returned from injury to score his second goal for the club in the fourth round of the [[2014-15 Football League Cup|League Cup]], opening the scoring in Newcastle's 2–0 away victory over holders [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29718452 |title=Holders Manchester City were knocked out of the League Cup as a youthful Newcastle side earned the club's first win in 12 attempts at Etihad Stadium. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 October 2014 |accessdate=29 October 2014 }} In early November, Aarons suffered a recurrence of his hamstring injury, ruling him out for another month.{{cite news|last1=Starforth|first1=Miles|title=Rolando Aarons blow for Newcastle|url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/sport/football/newcastle-united/rolando-aarons-blow-for-newcastle-1-6946258|accessdate=11 November 2014|work=[[Shields Gazette]]|date=11 November 2014}} ====Loans==== In 2018, Aarons spent time out on loan with [[Hellas Verona F.C.|Hellas Verona]] and [[FC Slovan Liberec|Slovan Liberec]].{{cite news|title=Aarons completes loan move|url=https://www.nufc.co.uk/news/latest-news/aarons-completes-loan-move|accessdate=7 September 2018|work=Newcastle United F.C.|date=7 September 2018}} After 13 appearances in all competitions for ''Modrobílí'', he returned to Newcastle in December 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.themag.co.uk/2018/12/newcastle-united-official-announcement-confirms-rolando-aarons-is-on-his-way-back/|title=Newcastle United official announcement confirms Rolando Aarons is on his way back|website=themag.co.uk|date=17 December 2018|accessdate=18 December 2018}} On 31 January 2019, deadline day for the winter transfer window, he signed for [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11678/11624144/west-brom-loan-jacob-murphy-sheffield-wednesday-sign-rolando-aarons-and-achraf-lazaar|title=Newcastle Trio Leave On Loan|publisher=Sky Sports|date=31 January 2019|accessdate= 31 January 2019}} == International career == Aarons is eligible to represent either [[England national football team|England]] or [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] at international level.{{cite news|last1=Douglas|first1=Mark|title=Newcastle United youngster Roland Aarons wanted by Championship clubs – and Jamaica|url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-united-youngster-roland-aarons-7585326|newspaper=[[The Journal (newspaper)|The Journal]]|accessdate=28 August 2014|date=9 August 2014}} In August 2014, he received his first call-up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England U-20 team]], marking his debut with the opening goal in a 6–0 friendly match win over [[Romania national under-20 football team|Romania]] on 5 September.{{cite web|title=Aidy Boothroyd names U20 squad to face Romania|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/aug/boothroyd-names-his-first-u20-squad|publisher=[[The FA]]|accessdate=28 August 2014|date=28 August 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Reid|first1=Jamie|title=Boothroyd's boys hit Romania for six in Telford|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/sep/england-v-romania-u20-match-report-050914|publisher=[[The FA]]|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=5 September 2014}} His club manager [[Alan Pardew]] confirmed that, despite interest from Jamaica, Aarons intended to pursue an international future within the England set-up.{{cite news|last=Starforth|first=Miles|title=Rolando Aarons will target England future, says Newcastle United boss at the time Alan Pardew |url=http://www.shieldsgazette.com/sport/football/newcastle-united/rolando-aarons-will-target-england-future-says-newcastle-united-boss-alan-pardew-1-6811613|newspaper=[[Shields Gazette]]|date=29 August 2014|accessdate=30 August 2014}} == Style of play == Aarons operates on the outside of midfield or as a winger, usually on the left side. He is left-footed and known for his injections of pace and technical ability.{{cite news|title=Rolando Aarons seeks a reward for his sterling effort at Newcastle|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/529614/Rolando-Aarons-seeks-a-reward-for-his-sterling-effort-at-Newcastle|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|accessdate=5 November 2014|date=31 October 2014}} He has been compared to [[Manchester City F.C|Manchester City]] winger [[Raheem Sterling]] in his playing style and in his descent; both are Jamaican-born English players. ==Personal life== Aarons was born in Kingston, Jamaica. He migrated to England at the age of 5 to join his mother who was already living in the city of Bristol.{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/newcastle-uniteds-brightest-best-freddie-8793133|title=Newcastle United's brightest and best: Freddie Woodman and Rolando Aarons aiming for the stars|first=Mark|last=Douglas|date=8 March 2015|publisher=}}. He is the cousin of [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] player [[Max Aarons]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city/ncfc-max-aarons-1-5678948|title=Rapid rise continuing for Canaries prospect Aarons after derby debut|last=Freezer|first=David|work=Eastern Daily Press|access-date=2018-09-04|language=en}} == Career statistics == {{updated|match played 21 October 2018}}{{Soccerway|rolando-aarons/360019}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+Club statistics |- !rowspan=2 width=140|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]]
